description:
I stopped by the Cable Car museum because of a giant smoke stack that caught my attention while walking by. I never knew how the whole cable car really worked so it intrigued me. 

It is free admission to get into the museum and so I didn't go very it a second thought and walked in. It was amazing to see the giant wheels operating. Apparently this facility powers the cable cars throughout San Francisco. If you go downstairs you can see the wheels underground as well. They had plenty of reading on the walls about the history and how the cable cars work. The whole thing made me want to get on a cable car so I bought a day pass and rode it back and forth several times. 

Really nice museum and pretty clean too! Very cool place! If you're by it you should definitely stop by!
author: Nico M.

description:
If you enjoyed riding the SF Cable Car, the United States' only moving National Monument, you should stop by the Cable Car Barn along the way and see how it works! This Museum IS the engine of all those Cable Cars you see out there, and their history, and yes... even a gift shop with lost of cool Cable Car doo-dads. You can get off the Cable Car at the Museum, with a transfer, on one of the lines (ask... I think it's the Mason Street line) and get back on right out front, all of which is at-no-cost! 
I bet there are many people who don't even know about this museum, even as they pass by it on the cable car.

The Museum is hands-on, and good for kids, interesting for Mom's and Dad's too! Not to mention that it has some great photo spots! It takes as little as a half hour to see everything there. (and they have bathrooms, too)

I have one suggestion, though.... Docents! It would be great if they had a docent or two, maybe in Cable Car Operator uniforms (historical and new) so people can ask questions, maybe snap a photo, etc. I bet there are some retirees and cable car buffs who would love to volunteer for such a fun job. Jus' sayin' .
author: James G.

description:
For a free museum, very cool.  My son thought that seeing how everything works under the street was just remarkably cool.  This place is small and will take you 15-20 minutes at most to look through, but it is worth doing. Probably not worth a separate trip, but a good stop in when you are in this part of San Francisco. 

Fun photos here.
author: Niki M.

description: This museum was such a gem of a find. It was really educational to learn about the underground components and mechanisms that run the San Francisco cable cars. Though a very small museum, there was a lot on display and plenty of information to soak in. Best part: it's free of charge.
author: Johnny Z.

description: Free Museum with a history of the San Francisco cable car system. It is small but when you visit it, you find out everything you need to know about the cable car, how it works and why it is still working.
author: Špela Š.

description: Very quaint yet informative museum! I was in Chinatown and saw that this was nearby so decided to walk over. Didn't have many expectations, but was fascinated by the space! This little museum operates all of the cable cars running through SF. How cool is that? I learned a lot about the inner workings of a cable car and its operations and also, the mechanisms haven't swayed too far from its original invention.. SO COOL. I know, super nerdy. But if you enjoy history and mechanisms, definitely check this place out!
author: Nancy N.

description: The Cable Car Museum is probably one of the most coolest free museums that San Francisco has to offer.  You are able to see how the cable cars actually work from under the street.  There is lots of history and old photographs of the cable cars.  It is very interesting and a great place to go to if you have an hour or so of free time.  Plus its free.  They have a little souvenir shop where proceeds go to support the museum.
author: Sara G.

description:
I moved to SF in '77 ( I think) and it only took me 40yrs to finally check out the Cable Car museum, which opened in 1974.  After moving to SoCal roughly 10 yrs ago, I always feel like a tourist when I go back to see friends. 

On a trip in early '17, I finally did it ... took the overhyped cable car ride and went to see the museum. 

There are no guides. There are no recorded guided tours either. You just walk up, take a look around, observe and read the plaques in front of the displays or check out the old photos on the wall. 

It's noisy in there, so conversations will turn into a shouting match.  Forget about talking on your phone. It's impossible.  It's not terribly big but there are decent photo ops to capture the history of SF and its famed cable cars. And a cool way to spend about an hour at most seeing how it all works. 

It wasn't very packed in there when we went on a Saturday since for tourists, there are many other 'touristy' things to do. But there was a steady flow of peeps walking in. 

If you're in the area, it's worth a visit!  

Notes:
* Free entry.  Can't beat that. 
* There's a souvenir store inside. Not surprising
* Unless you're an awesome driver and master at parking, I'd advise public transit, cab or walk.
* Def bring a camera & take pics. 
* Wheelchair accessible on side of building, w elevator. 
* There are public restrooms inside.
author: James L.

description:
Located on the corner of Mason and Washington Street, this museum is The BARN and wheelhouse of the cable cars running in San Francisco.  This is where ALL the power comes from along with it's rich history.  Words can not explain the powerful and rich history of the cable car, how it was invented, why it was invented, who invented THIS cable car system, and how it works ..... YOU MUST VISIT IT to find out!

I can give you all the photos and videos of the museum, or the Barn, but it gives only a glimpse into what this place really does. When you are in SF, please take the cable car UP to the Barn/museum and look around ...... FREE ADMISSION!
author: Randy L.

description: Great, eye-opening experience. Never knew this was how cable cars worked. Awesome history to read and watch; extremely detailed. Free admission.
author: Attosa C.

description:
In A Nutshell:

-It's pretty cool to see how the cable cars work in SF.
-This small museum details how they work & they are still operational!
-You can check everything out in less than 15-20 minutes.

Overall, the next time you find yourself over cable car tracks, look between the crack to see the cable & you'll know how it works.
author: Romeo K.

description:
SF is the only place in the world with cable cars. I found this museum to be interesting and informative. This is the site where the cables are operated. It is loud and smells like machinery. About 26 cable cars run at the same time and don't mistake them for trolley cars. 

I learned that cable cars were a cheaper and cleaner way of transportation than horses in the 1800s. Easier for going up hill. Hallidie received $30,000 loan from Wells Fargo for the project and other investors didn't think it would work. 

Former cable cars and signs are on display. Learn how the cable has changed throughout the years. You can look at old SF pics and learn about the Quake of 1906. There is seating to watch a short video about cable car history. There are models and saved memorabilia. The museum is free. Buying a souvenir at the gift shop will support the museum.
author: Julie S.

description: This is a must see museum for tourist. This museum is all about the San Francisco cable cars. This museum shows you some of the older cable cars that are in service anymore. I came to this museum to check it out because I had not been here before. I got to see a lot of things about the cable car that I never knew and never seen before. There is also a video here that talks about the cable cars. This museum is admission free.
author: Isaac H.

description:
In his review from December, Yelper James L said it best:  "it only took me 40 years...".

Silly, but true, it took that long for the Cable Car Museum to rise to become a part of my day.  Let's face it, it's not the place one thinks of when imagining a "museum day" nor is it the experience that comes to mind when envisioning cable cars.  Certainly a visit to SF's MOMA or a ride on the Powell-Hyde line is a better experience but there's only one of those experiences that's free.  

Welcome to SF's Cable Car Museum; free and worth about 40 minutes of your time.  

It's not well known, but San Francisco's history includes a time when independently owned cable cars traversed the city.  Imagine being able to lay down tracks and start your own cable car company on a whim and you can see why this wasn't a sustainable proposition.  

Then imagine a San Francisco without cable cars.  It almost happened and, were it not for the efforts of one particularly tenacious person, it might have.  

What did the City look like in the immediate aftermath of the 1906 earthquake and fires?  Interesting and compelling.

The Cable Car Museum covers all of this and more in a clean, well organized, informative space featuring lots of photos, stories, cables, and (grounded) cable cars.  It also features a non-stop, low-level din, from the active cables.  Think of it as a clean and informative machine-shop.

If you too wait 40 years to visit I suspect the whole thing will remain much the same but if you're in the neighborhood (Nob Hill or Chinatown) or looking for a reason to be, the Cable Car Museum is an interesting little sideline to whatever else you might have planned for the day.  

Free and interesting:  It's the way I aspire to spend most days.  The Cable Car Museum is a solid if not particularly exciting experience.
author: Tracey A.

description:
A FREE MUSEUM! The Cable Car Museum Celebrates The 50th Anniversary of The Summer of Love. Learn how the famous cable cars of San Francisco really work. Watch the moving underground cables turn on giant wheels as they transport the citizens to various parts of the city via the cable cars. You can get up close to some of those beautiful vintage cable cars as well. They also have a gift store here to purchase various take home souvenirs. Be sure to visit the lower level too.  
It used to be, you had to have mega bucks & be really rich to have the Good Life, not anymore. The Game has changed. You've been Upgraded. Now You Can 
Live Like a King on a Limited Budget!
author: Stephen Z.

description:
Seriously, how cool is this little place. I am simply amazed to see their large wheels/cogs pulling the huge cables that are actually pulling cars throughout downtown.  

Unique. Historical. Amazing to see in person!  And it is free (although they would love donations).  

Super cool place that is a can't miss.
author: Jessica J.

description: Great for a free museum.  Loved how you can learn the history about SF cable car and a great place for a little one to run around - open space.  They had a little gift shop where you could see stuff.  We we're kind of disappointed that they didn't have an actual cable car for guests to sit in and take a photo.  I suppose you can take a photograph of a cable car at fisherman's wharf but it is after all a cable car museum.  Fun if you would like to rest/take a break while walking around.  It can kill about 30-45 minutes.
author: Grace W.

description: This is a "hidden jewel" among San Francisco museums that is a MUST-SEE for both visitors & residents!! It is open on Mondays (when most other museums are closed) and is free admission. In addition to the fascinating ups & downs history (pun intended...) the cable car inner workings can be seen in real-time. Photos & vids online do not compare - see them in person. ALSO at rear wall don't miss wonderful photos of San Francisco 1906 earthquake & fire, many never published. Museum is easily accessed via Powell-Mason cable car, which stops one block away. After your visit, take Powell-Hyde cable car to Fisherman's Wharf & Ghirardelli Square. Do not miss this!
author: Kate L.

description:
We stumbled on the Cable Car Museum as part of a walking around visit to the city. It was an interesting find and worth a visit.

Cable cars are the quintessential San Francisco landmark. The cars look and feel as though they are from another era. And, in fact, they are from another era. The Cable Car museum demonstrates the extent to which this is the case.

The machines that run the cable cars appear to be from the late 1800's. The date listed on one of the machines is from a Philadelphia company from 1892. They are loud and obviously well built.

The museum has plaques showing how the cables are made, when they were invented, and when the system was implemented and how it was saved from destruction.

There is a gift shop to buy a souvenir. This may be the only place to get the Cable Car museum t-shirt!

It is free and worth a visit.
author: Ralph S.

description:
Convenient and free this little SF gem is worth checking out.

The basement provides only some viewing windows to the running cables underground while a few steps to the main floor provide a visual and educational experience, which may be a little loud for sensitive ears.

This main floor is an immense viewing platform over the running motors that pull the four lines of cable i.e. Hyde, California, Mason and Powell through our San Francisco streets as well as the machine shop.  Here, anyone can watch this operation as long as one wants. Two old cable cars are on display yet not accessible to the public. Also, an historical and educational video plays in an endless loop. And a gift shop sells souvenirs that include used pieces of the actual Cable Car Cable (heavy wire rope) for about $35. 

The floors above are not open to the public but do include the barn where the cable cars sleep at night and offices for management. This is not an all day event. I doubt if most spend even an hour here.
author: Caesar A.

description:
Way cool to see the operational cables flowing!  

Yes the displays are interesting in and of themselves but to see the larges wheels, motors and lines all moving and realizing what it takes to move thousands of people up and down the hills of SF everyday is pretty amazing.

Worth a quick visit in the least.
author: Christopher S.

description: Love going to a free museum and learn a bit of history. See the original cable cars, the cables at work above and underground. A great stop and not too many tourists crowding the place
author: Jennifer U.

description: Everybody loves FREE and this little museum is great for those interested in history, cables cars, the mechanics of them, or just cool stuff in general. The best part is seeing the cables in action working the routes. It can be very loud for people who have sensitive hearing, but it's so neat to watch! There are some old cable car units on display, the history/evolution of cable cars, and a big spool of the cable that you can touch. It's always nice to see behind the curtain and learn how things operate. Head downstairs to see the bigger machinery in action before you go.
author: Nikita H.

description:
Nice museum - a good place to spend a little time and learn about cable cars. It's interesting to see the wheels turning the cables that are powering all of the cable cars in SF. Historical information and gift shop is upstairs. (Note: they don't sell tickets to ride the cable cars -you will simply pay cash or credit card once you're on a car) 
After our visit we walked one block and rode a cable car to fisherman's wharf, hopped off at the end of the line, then boarded another cable car back up the hill and over to Union Square. Cars stop every 8-12 minutes. Cost is $21 for a full day unlimited or $7 per ride.
author: Joanne P.

description: This was an awesome little aside to our wanderings of SF. It's free to go in and you can wander around and see all the giant gears and cables, and take pictures of some old trolleys.
author: Jason J.

description:
Not a huge museum by any means, but a free one is always a bonus! The SF Cable cars are iconic and the only ones like it left in the world. Sure, its a touristy thing and cars and the like have definitely replaced them, but I enjoyed seeing and learning about them from this museum. It's like enjoying the beauty and intricateness of a fine old fashioned timepiece in the face of digital watches and smartwatches.

Plan to spend maybe an hour here, tops. That's not including if you go out and ride a cable car afterwards of course. We walked out to the Hyde street stop and took it up the hill to Lombard street since that was next on our list anyway, efficient!
author: Desmond F.

description:
I've been wanting to come here for awhile and finally got the chance. It's free admission and a historic landmark! 

It's a quick trip in even if you read everything.  Nice to see a piece of history that is also currently being used in SF.
author: Melissa L.

description:
Watch the central nexus and terminus, of the cables and massive gears as they pull the cable cars through the streets of San Francisco in real time.
Your kids will love this!  The history and mechanics are also fascinating for adults.
author: Colleen H.

description:
Surprisingly fascinating...if you have an hour or two to burn, go ahead and check this place out.  The history of cable cars is really interesting and if you have even a passing interested in the engineering aspects, you'll truly enjoy this.

Amazing to know learn of what's happen just below your feet!
author: J H.

description:
Cable Car ride is one of the top things to do when visiting San Francisco. Ever wonder how it works? This museum is an excellent solution for your wondering mind.

I bookmarked here just about six months ago after seeing a review by one of the SF resident Yelper. His pictures and review was written so well, I bookmarked it to visit someday.

It's free. Upstairs some history and display of old cable cars. You get to see the wheels in motion. I really enjoyed learning all about Cable Cars in San Francisco. They have nice gift shop. I purchased miniature cable car Christmas ornament while there. I purchase one Christmas ornament every year for my tree to remember from that year. I thought something to represents San Francisco is just so perfect this year.

It's not huge but good place to spend just about an hour. Stop by while you are in town. Will have a whole new outlook towards the Cable Car.
author: Yuko H.

description: This is a FREE self-guided tour with very interesting information. You can see the large wheels turn pulling the cables of the city. Great place!
author: Dan F.

description:
How did I miss this all my life until last weekend?  When you are the only female with a group of guys from 12 to 60-something, this pick for a visit worked really well!

Even better, it was free.  Finding parking nearby is tricky, but we managed.  Entering the brick building, I immediately felt the history within the walls.

An ear assault occurs, as the cable reels that drive the four lines are right there, spinning away.  You can either view from above, or walk downstairs under street level for a closer look.

The museum portion isn't that large, but packed with tales of how the cable car system came about and evolved. 

There was also great competition among multiple independent companies in the 19th century.  Those stories are told, plus a look at the chaos after the Great Earthquake. 

Several historic cable cars provide backdrop to the space.

There is a gift shop on the premises with all manner of SF memorabilia, focusing on cable car images, natch.

Glad we visited the practical home of the mighty little railcars that climb the hills of the city by the Bay.  After, we had to go ride one!
author: Lianne K.

description:
Anyone who thinks of San Francisco, thinks of their famous cable cars. Wanna know more about them and how they work? Come to this place. It provides a great overview of the history and inner workings of cable cars in the city. 

In addition to a museum, this place is the actual point of operation for all the cable cars in the city. You can watch the cable actually being powered, look at them in operation, and learn lots of their history and inner workings. You can even see the progression of car design and styles. For anyone interested in transportation, or even just San Fran History, this is a must see stop ok your visit to the city.
author: Chris W.

description:
If you're visiting San Francisco and don't ride the cable cars even once, then you're doing it wrong.  It was while riding them that the wife and I heard about the Cable Car Museum and it was free.  We had lots of time to kill so we thought, "Why not?"

The Cable Car Museum sat on the corner of Mason and Washington Streets in Nob Hill.  While the structure was of large, most of the interior square footage of the building was dedicated to the mechanical operations of the cable car system.  As you'd expect, the museum contained the history through pictures, words, and exhibits of one of the city's signature and most iconic sights.  Touring the museum was self-guided, self-paced.  Displays were straightforward.  While it took less than an hour to take it all in, it was very informative and answered all of my questions on how it all worked.  The Cable Car Museum was the museum I never knew that I needed to see.  It was definitely worth our time, made all the better by being free.
author: Gregg M.

description:
Good place to burn 15-30 minutes and learn about cable cars in SF.  
Free admission.  See moving parts spinning in action.  There is a bathroom and small gift shop.
author: Tommy C.

description: Great background and history on this SF gem. Highly recommend a visit and you can't beat the admission price - free!
author: JoAnne P.

description: If you're looking for something cool to do and kill time, this is definitely a place to go. It's free and full of cool stuff. I highly recommend it!
author: Eric v.

description: It's a free museum and you can check out how the cable cars function. Small but worth a visit if you're into that sort of thing. Right in Chinatown so stop by some dim sum afterwards.
author: Barbara D.

description:
Great place to spend an hour. The museum is FREE and has some great pieces of history, including the last surviving original cable car.

Some great detailed history about cable cars, their role in early San Fran. all the way up to the current time!

Nice, clean place. The only reason I did not give 5 stars is because the two employees at the gift shop were surly. A guy and a lady.... acted bothered that people were trying to give them money. Oh well!

Overall a great, FREE place to visit!
author: Andrew M.

description: This museum was great! We loved that it was free and could spend 15 minutes and go to the restroom without having to pay. You can see the cables working underground and read about the history and workings of the cable cars. There is also a gift shop if you are interested in memorabilia.
author: Erica W.

description:
Great museum where you can learn a lot.
Best part is it's free.
Dont forget to watch the movie about cable cars to learn abt these san francisco icons.

The gift shop is pretty good, soveniers are available for reasonable prices for the City of San Francisco.

Clean restrooms are great advantage.

An hour well-spent!
author: Zeba S.

description:
1 - The place is free!
2 - It's within walking distance from downtown and chinatown
3 - Cool history about the cable car and even the development of San Francisco
4 - They have restrooms open for public use
author: Ray L.

description: Cool little museum to visit. You can probably spend 20-30 mins and see everything, but if you're into mechanical things it will be worth it.
author: Andrew R.

description:
Mongo like cable. Mongo like cars. Mongo like museums. And Mongo see all three here. Mongo look at old cable cars. Mongo buy sourdough bread starter. And everybody nice to Mongo. And then Mongo watch big, big wheel go round and round and round and round. 

Then Mongo get dizzy...
author: Mongo I.

description:
Not just a museum but also an essential functioning part of the cable car system.

It's roughly two blocks away from chinatown, but about three ish blocks away from the part of chinatown that you'll be interested in seeing. It is a stop on the cable car line itself which offers a neat way to go see the museum. Should you chose to visit via cable car you'd be best served by buying one of the all day packages so's you can enjoy the rest of the cable car line. Or you could just pay as you go.

The museum is only partly a museum-it's also the power station, rewinding center(for the cable part of the cable car) and a maintenance depot. Also of course one of the original buildings used for the cable car system. Due to all this the building is really noisy. You'll have a hard time hearing anything when the cable winding is in session. Unless you are an engineer or otherwise fascinated by the cable car system this will take you 30 mins or so to cover which leaves plenty of time to watch the cable people outside, or to grab a pint at the place across the street,

Not an essential must do for SF, but it is totally free, fun, and quirky. Also the most comprehensive place to learn about the cable car system both current and historical in San Francisco.
author: Steven W.

description: The cable cars were the highlight of our day trip to San Francisco and the museum/cable car barn is a brilliant testament to the hard working men and women that keep this treasure running. It made us happy to know that things and places like this still exist. Thank you!!!
author: Lisa G.

description:
This museum is free so I wasn't really expecting much. But I'm so glad we stopped by - it was so cool to see the inner workings of the infamous cable cars and learn about their history. 

I read this was a good place to get on the cable car, but I actually wish we hadn't. If you're really interested in getting a full ride, go to either end of the line. Getting on at the museum means you only get to ride half the distance (and it's not cheap at $7 per person!). 

Definitely recommend stopping by this museum to learn the difference between a cable car and a street car!
author: Amanda F.

description: This may be one of the only top notch attractions in San Francisco that is "free." That alone makes it worth a visit.  However, it also both a museum and a working operation.   You can actually see the cables and how they work to drag those iconic cars up and down the steep hills of the City By The Bay.   Well worth a visit.  By the way, it's located on a cable car line in case you need a lift.
author: Buddy F.

description: FREE! Why not. While catching the cable cars from Union Square, stop by the cable care museum before you hit fisherman's wharf. You can easily go through the museum in an easy 30-45minutes or less. It's pretty interesting to see how and when it all first started and how the cable cars itself function. Once you've gained some knowledge, your whole experience on riding the cable cars changes. You might even have a better appreciation for them. Who knew that the maximum speed was 9 mph. Didn't know that til I visited the museum.
author: Christal C.

description:
I love this museum. It's free, so I bring all my guests. I feel like I've stepped into the last century when I'm here. I love the sound of the cables going out into the city.

Make sure you go downstairs to see the tunnels.
author: Lauren R.

description: Such a cool place, and it's free!  The cable car museum, which is on a cable car line provides a view of a working cable car operation and provides a great historical overview of the cable car system.
author: David C.

description:
At first blush, this may not seem like the most interesting spot to visit.  I stumbled across it one day when I took a visitor to the top of Nob Hill to see beautiful Huntington Park, Grace Cathedral, and the historically posh SF Hotels.  Next stop, down to North Beach and find a Bloody Mary, stat.  We stumbled upon this place and it is really worth checking out.

I thought Cable Cars were sort of a quirky little novelty for my first year or so living in SF.  My attitude has since turned.  Part of that change was based on learning more about the history.  There's a reason why we have Cable Cars - it's the hills.  As The City developed, the Cable Cars were how the folks in the olden days expanded beyond the low-lying areas in the (now) FiDi, SoMa and North Beach.  (We're talking in the days when North Beach was actually a beach.)  

This museum has a great range of history, including:

*Andrew Hallidie, the engineer who made cables and was instrumental in the mining technology.  The story goes, he saw a horse drawn carriage slide backward down a steep muddy hill.  Our Cable Car version of Mr. Newton's apple.
*History about the older lines and their impact on SF development.  There were a lot more lines, once upon a time.  You can see how they were laid out, and you can also see how the companies thrived or failed.
*Friedel Klussmann "The Cable Car Lady" - Who saved the Cable Cars from their potential final demise.  She formed the Citizens' Committee to Save the Cable Cars and won a referendum in 1947.  BTW - A big mid-finger salute to then short-sighted Republican Mayor Roger Lapham who was trying to scrap the Cable Cars because he came under fire for increasing the fares.  He was a one-termer.
*Some great info about the massive restoration that took place in the early-80's.  And, a super awesome 80's-style video about the Cable Cars.  

Another big reason to check this out is that it is also the power-house that actually drives the cables.  You can see the major lines that drive the little systems that pulls the cars along.  Very cool.  They also have a nice gift shop.
author: Adam S.

description: Loved this museum, it's a quick stop and you can jump on different cable cars just outside.
author: Charlotte B.

description: Mother and I checked this place out on her last visit to San Francisco pretty cool place interesting to read about the history. Amazing that those big wheels and Motors can make all that weight roll around the whole town. If you get a chance check it out pretty cool history.
author: Steve W.

description: Great place to stop by before hopping on a cable car.  It's a free museum and provides lots of history as well as tons of information related to the operations of the cable car system in San Francisco.  It's also the hub at which engines run all the cable car lines in San Francisco.  Pretty amazing to see.  You get a real appreciation for the ride, once you've spend 30 minutes in this museum.  Make sure you also go downstairs to see the underground cables in action.
author: Brian K.

description: Unique museum (given that we're the only city with working cable cars) but very noisy. Free to the public, but somewhat hard to get to given the transit-unfriendliness of the neighborhood it's in.
author: Anees L.

description: It is worth the walk to see the operation of the cable car system.  It's amazing how the cable system is centralized in one location to control all the cable cars.   Take into consideration that this technology is 100 years old and still in use today.
author: Michael Scott P.

description: Neat little free museum that explains the history of cable cars in San Francisco. A lot of old photos of the great earthquake and how it changed the cable car business. You can also see how the cables run under the streets.
author: Dan S.

description: A bit loud, but a fun place to visit.  Free admission and a really lovely, informative place.  But so loud!
author: Tom T.

description:
The Admission: FREE!!!

If you want to see cable cars... come to this block, there will be cable cars pass by every few minutes!

This museum is very informative. Many display, video, photos and historic cable car inside the museum. 

The museum is not too big but definitely worth it to check it out.
author: Cassandra Y.

description: The cable cars are hard to explain to friends visiting San Francisco, especially tourists that have never been on a bus, let alone a cable car. You would be surprised to see how many people visiting the City by the Bay have never been on a subway, bus, train, or cable car. Taking your friends to the cable car museum is a grand experience in ingenuity, gravity, and they will carry the knowledge forever especially when they go back home to explain to their friends the true dynamics of the amazing cable cars that ride people throughout San Francisco. Your friends will remember the experience of learning in the cable car museum every time they think of their visit with you in San Francisco.
author: Thomas Chase Leo S.

description:
I recommend the cable car to everyone, including local residents who have missed it.  It only takes 15 minutes and shows how cable cars work throughout san francisco.  It completely changes the way you look at these vehicles as they pass.  

Definitely worth a 15 minute stop in.
author: William V.

description:
Another must-see stop if you're a tourist, are curious to know the history of cable cars and how they operate, or just want to be fascinated! And best part is, it's all free!

This museum on the corner of Mason and Washington has a very inviting open entrance along with a Powell-Hyde cable car stop right by it, so it is very accessible! Once you enter, you'll realize how jam-packed with artifacts and information this organized museum is, displaying enough historic pictures and models of the actual cable cars of yesteryear to keep you intrigued in each exhibit for a long while! Once you have learned about the intricacies of how cable cars operate as well as their evolution, it's time to see it all in action.

The even cooler part of this museum is the fact that once you go downstairs, you get to witness the actual cables being operated in real time! It is loud, fast, and super interesting. Plus, there's something about that old cable smell that's kind of comforting... 

Overall, terrific museum, you'll definitely walk out with some new information. And don't forget to ring the bell! :)
author: Kyrie S.

description: Pretty cool spot. Free but donations welcome. My 7 year old really liked it. Check out the downstairs. Good way to spend 30-45 minutes.
author: Maria C.

description:
Hop aboard and learn about the iconic cable cards that glide along the streets throughout the city. The museum is FREE and shares great information on the history of the cable cars. It is incredible how much work is still done by hand to keep the cable cars moving, and it was fun to watch the cables and wheels turn as well as taking a trip to the basement of the museum to check out the cables underground. 
Tour the museum and then go ride a cable car to complete your cable car experience.
author: Kim K.

description:
Sitting right between quintessential Nob Hill and famous San Francisco China Town, the Cable Car Museum is a must hit spot for anyone visiting San Francisco. It's free so there is really no excuse to not go see it! 

Stepping into the museum you're offered two choices, up or down. Down will take you to a small space with windows to watch the cables for the cable cars run into tunnels that will help carry the cable cars around the city. Upstairs you find a birds eye view of the large rotating cables, a peek into some classic cable cars, and tons of history. Its a fascinating stop!
author: Kari G.

description: File this under "Mildly Interesting" for lack of a better description. I enjoy history. My boyfriend enjoys engineering. We're both cheapskates, ahem, I mean frugal, and this free museum came highly recommended to us by a friend. I thought it'd be a great fit for us. And there were a couple of really cool things to see here, don't get me wrong. It was just disappointingly small once we got inside, especially since we walked very much out of our way to get here. We read every plaque, took many pictures, and spent long moments admiring the cables loudly spinning and rolling their way through the museum, but it still only took us 45 minutes to get through the whole thing. Luckily it was free. I would only stop by here if you're really into cable cars, or if you just happen to walk by and have half an hour to kill.
author: Katie H.

description: On my walk from Grace Cathedral in Nob Hill to Chinatown, I randomly passed the Cable Car Museum and stopped in. Didn't know it existed before. It's a very cool and small FREE museum for an individual or families. You could spend between 5-30 minutes here: reading history, checking out artifacts, taking pictures, seeing the machinery downstairs, exploring old cable cars, and just generally learning how they run.
author: Marc B.

description:
This was an excellent museum, and totally free admission! If you like the TV show "How it's Made", this is the real life version of it. You can see in action all the cables moving and how the cable cars work. There is a good video that is a little dated, but the cable cars still work the same, so ignore the hair styles and you'll be good. 

It's also a great history of San Francisco. There are great images that explain how the city was before The Earthquake. The pictures will keep younger kids involved, and parents can read the highlights of the text to them. 

If you're a science/ mechanical person, you can easily nerd out here for an hour. For the rest of our group, they spent about 20-40 minutes here and then walked two blocks to China Town to shop. 

They have clean restrooms too. The gift shop closed at about 4:40pm (20 minutes before the museum closed).
author: Kate V.

description: Really cool to see the big cables turn, and you can't beat free admission when everything else in the city is fairly costly. Make sure you ride the cable car to get there!
author: Nicholas H.

description:
The price is right for this museum as it is FREE! Being on the corner of Washington and Mason you get to see two cable car routes combine; one comes straight down Washington and the other swings into Washington from Mason. When you enter the museum and go downstairs you can see the cable wheels turning as well as upstairs where you can see the cables from above. There is enough reading matter and demonstration pieces to appreciate how these cars are operating....and you don't have to be an engineer to be suitably impressed.
We made ourselves an excursion to get there. We walked to the turnaround at Hyde then stayed on the cable car passing the museum on the way to town. We could have caught the cable car back ( the queue was horrendous ) but instead we walked to 3rd and caught No 45 bus to get us up the hill with a short walk to the museum.
The coffee shop across the road is pretty good too as you can't take or buy food or drink at the museum.
author: Sue L.

description:
If you're someone who likes to learn how things work mechanically then you really need to check out the Cable Car Museum. You can learn how the cable cars work including how to drive them, how the brakes work, how the cables are pulled - and even see the pulleys at work! Best of all it's free. It's old school. Even before steam. Lots of local history as well.

It's a small museum so don't expect to spend more than 30-60 minutes here. Perfect.
author: Jean K.

description: It's not as big asI was hoping for and I sure wish there would be more children friendly language for them to appreciate the history of the charm and timeless magic of the cable car.
author: Lesley M. C.

description:
The Cable Car Museum is a hidden gem!!

I didn't know about this place, but when researching places to visit in the city it popped up as the top ten places to visit!! Located along the Cable Car line, it is easy to access. I would recommend hopping on the Cable Car at Ghirardelli Square (where they start) and taking it up to the museum (the guys operating the cable cars will tell you when to get off). A Cable Car ride is $6 for one way, or you can buy a day pass for something like $17. I'd also recommend getting to the cars early....I got there around 9am and there was no wait (once it gets close to 11am, there will be a very long wait!). 

Onto the museum. The Cable Car Museum is FREE, which is amazing!! This place is small, so allow yourself about 45 minutes to explore the entire place (60 minutes maybe if you want to check out the gift shop!). There are so many pictures and descriptions of the cable cars -- it is truly awesome how cable cars have evolved over the years. There is also the only remaining cable car from 1872 at this museum too! I loved seeing the old pictures from the late 1800's and how people traveled from place to place in the city at the time. You can also see all the cables that operate the current cable cars in the city and the men and women that operate them. I was so fascinated by this aspect -- I had no idea that the operation to operate the cable cars was so huge! Pure awesomeness!

Side note: there is a free and clean restroom to use in this museum, which is rare and hard to find in the city. Just FYI. 

I'd recommend coming here, no matter if you're a tourist or a local!

Cheers!
author: Michelle M.

description: I come to San Francisco for work relatively often, and find myself walking between SoMa and the Wharf all the time. Through all my visits, I had not yet checked out the Cable Car Museum, and was happy I finally did.  The museum is a very interesting look at the history of San Francisco's unique cable cars, and how the system works. The museum is rather nondescript and you might miss it, but it's right along one of the cable car routes so just keep your eyes peeled. Admission is free: you just walk right in and stroll around at your own pace. There's a decent amount of content to read and take pictures of. Expect to spend about 15-30 minutes here, depending on how interested you are in cable cars. Overall a great free way to kill some time in SF.
author: Ho L.

description:
The cable car museum is fun and educational for kids and adults!  Read about the history of the cable cars... see how they work, snap some photos, watch a video and then visit their cute little gift shop! 

This museum is worth visiting.. come on it's free.. what more can you ask for?  Pretty neat to see all the wheels turning.  We didn't spend more than an hour here, but it was nice!  Come check it out, make a donation, and learn a little about a large part of San Francisco: cable cars!
author: Betty H.

description: What a great free museum! 2 of the cable cars will pass by this museum. If you have time to peek, it's definitely a great bit of history and for this city. The mechanics about how they run is fascinating. Lots oh cool behind the scenes views of what's going on under the cars.
author: Kay A.

description:
The Cable Car Museum is a small museum where you can learn about San Francisco's cable car history and see a live "behind the scenes" look at the cable car pulley system.  The old-timey, vintage museum is located inside one of the "powerhouses," where a power source is used to drive the cables.  It's cool and interesting to look at.  The best part about the museum is admission is free.

The museum is located at the corner of Washington and Mason Streets in Nob Hill, very close to Chinatown.  A cable car stop is located right outside.  The museum is two stories and contains old cable cars, cable car parts, old photographs, video exhibits, and a gift shop.  Most of your time will probably be spent on the upper floor where most of the aforementioned items are located.

The upper floor looks down upon the Washington-Mason cable car barn.  You can see the giant pulleys that run the cables down the Hyde, California, Mason, and Powell lines in action.  Each is labeled.  You can also see the offices and work stations of cable car employees.  It's a peek into their operations.  The lower floor is underground and gives you a look at the pulleys and sheaves (a sheave is a type of pulley) that constantly run the cables underneath the street.  It gives you a new perspective of the cable cars you see running above ground.

Restrooms are located on the upper level.

A trip to the Cable Car Museum doesn't take very long.  Maybe 15-30 minutes, more if you plan to read all the interpretive panels and watch all the videos.  I wouldn't say this is a must-see attraction if you're visiting from out of town, but it's fascinating if you enjoy history or like to see how stuff works.
author: Daniel B.

description:
I can't believe I have only heard of this place but have never stepped in here until today. I am glad I made the move to come here. The Cable Car Museum is free for residents and visitors. This place focuses on the history of Cable Cars in San Francisco. If you are majoring in Electrical or Mechanical Engineering, then Cable Car Museum is your destination. Coming here will definitely help you gain a broader understanding on how motors work.

Overall, positive first time experience here so I'll definitely come back when I am in the area!

Have out of town family and friends visiting? This is also another great spot to visit especially if you are someone who enjoy learning about the history of Cable Cars.

Disclosure:
There is a gift shop here as well and some the merchandise on the shelves are pricey. Be prepared to have extra cash with you if you do plan buying something from the gift shop.

P.S.: They accept credit card payments - Visa and MasterCard ONLY!!

Their hours of operation for 4/1-9/30 are: 10 am - 6 pm and 10/1-3/31: 10 am - 5 pm
*They are closed on Nwe Year's Day, Easter, Thanksgiving and Christmas*
author: Bennett W.

description:
I'm a fan of nearly all museums, but this one just didn't do it for me. If the museum were not free, I'd have given it two stars. Parking in the area is nonexistent, so plan to pay for a garage or arrive by public transit--a cable car would be best.

There are really only two reasons to come to this museum. 
A) You are  a tourist with an interest in cable cars and your hotel/airbnb is within a 1/2 mile radius of this place, so you can walk to it easily. Sure, why not check it out? It's not a bad way to pass 30 minutes, which is about all you need to see it all.
B) You love cable cars. Maybe you or someone in your family works or worked in this industry and this place might have some additional meaning to you. 

Overall, the place was loud and kind of dirty. Exhibits were on the older side and not very well maintained. It is more of a working cable car depot with a viewing platform/balcony where you can view the lines and see the machinery (which is impressive), rather than a museum.

Unless, you are in category A or B above, I would skip this one.
author: Becca D.

description: The best part of my trip to San Francisco. I walked up the largest hills of my life (SF hills are no joke) and made it to the cable car museum all sweaty but it was worth it! What an incredible experience to see the technology behind the cable cars. More impressive is that fact the cable lines in the museum are operating the actual cable cars on the street! There are old cable cars, old wheels, old parts, beautiful old photographs and an education video in the museum that explains how they work, how they turn around etc. There's a small gift shop and a few spots to just sit and relax for a few moments. If you have a little time in your visit, it's worth it!
author: Lauren Y.

description:
It's a free exhibit but very interesting. Although I would prefer a small your about the history of cable cars. Even a small video will be great. It was close to Chinatown so we also toured around that historic place as well
.
author: Carol X.

description: Great little Place to go. Loud due to the cable machines going, wide open spaces for kids to run amuck and clean. Lots of history and bear part it is free!
author: Adam C.

description: I found the museum boring, has few old cars 3 or 4 and some old posts about the cable car, all you need in that museum is like 20 minutes, but the good part that it is free. If you are not passing the museum to your destination, don't bother driving to it.
author: Hani G.

description: You definitely need to make a stop. It's really informative and only takes about an hour to view
author: Ashley S.

description:
We stumbled upon this museum and I was surprised by how exciting (maybe a bit of an exaggeration) it actually was. If you're as touristy as we were when we were visiting SF and looking to learn a little bit about how the cable cars work and the history behind them you should definitely spend 15-20 min here. 

They have a bunch of info cards and posters about the cable car and its history but I thought that the real gem was actually being able to see the cables that move underground throughout the city. That was what transformed the experience beyond just simply reading a Wikipedia article about the cable car system.
author: Neechi M.

description:
This museum is worth a stop to see. FREE- self guided tour with plenty of info to read.  Especially fun for locals, yet I will go out on a limb here, but I'll bet few have ever ventured in.  This is a great part of our local history, very interesting and a welcome break from the otherwise touristy attractions we seek out for all our out of town guests. Nice gift shop too if you like that sort of thing.
Street parking can be difficult but not a long walk from Grace Cathedral, the Fairmont or the Cable Car line.
author: Linda T.

description: I thought this was one of the coolest things I've ever seen. I've been to San Francisco loads of times but never done the cable cars or been to the museum. We rode the Hyde line up to the museum and getting to see the powerhouse and how it all works was totally fascinating. They have loads to look at and you'll really be able to understand the mechanics of the entire system after visiting. Plus, entry is free! Small gift shop as well sells some cool stuff, like pieces of used cable.
author: Sarah K.

description: Did not know this museum existed until recently! It was totally amazing to see all these cables running through that pulls the cable cars. The museum wasn't very big, so it's a quick tour inside. But a fun and educational one for the kids. If you are in the neighborhood, it's definitely worth a while to drop by for a visit.
author: Patti S.

description:
I was walking towards Market Street to get on the Bart train to head to Berkeley. I saw this place on my map and thought why not since this city is known for it. Plus I needed a break from all those hills. I was breaking a sweat haha. 

Anyway this place is small but the best part....it's free! There are two floors. Upstairs is the gift shop and the "museum part" where you get to learn a little bit of history. Downstairs is the workings of the system. It's a neat little place to visit
author: Jimmy P.

description:
One of the best transportation and transportation history museums on the planet. This place is much more than a museum, it's a working system there for you to see. I daresay most people in San Francisco have no idea how the cable cars work. After ten minutes in this place you will be mesmerised and well-educated.

Everything about this Museum is amazing, the smell, the sites, the workers, the videos, the pictures hanging on the wall. Few places in San Francisco you'll find such a comprehensive collection of earthquake photos.

The only thing challenging about this museum is the nearby parking. It's all curbside, and your orbit the block for at least 20 minutes before you find a place. I'm not sure I recommend taking the cable car here because once you get off you might not get back on. Cable cars are crowded.

After the cable car museum walk across the street to the Gallery Cafe and grab a snack or a cup of coffee. It's an outstanding addition to your visit.
author: scott h.

description:
More Than Expected

It's not a big museum, but it is definitely worth an hour or two of your time.  If the only thing you see is the system that moves the cables, you will come away impressed.  There is more to see, but it is amazing to realize there are four cables dragging the cars around town.

Oh, and it's free!
author: Ted Q.

description: Stopped by here at this museum while we rode the cable car from ghiradelli square.  The outside of museum looked like this place would be pretty large in size and from reading all the other reviews, but once we got inside, it was actually pretty small.  Going downstairs does not even see much either.  It was fun and cool to see how the cable cars are run but really, you can be finished with checking this place out in probably 10 minutes!  There is a small gift shop area that has some unique items and nice they have restrooms for the kids.  I think if you are new to the area and visiting SF, this is a great place to check out at least once in your life is good enough.
author: Michael C.

description: San Fran is known for its cable cars. I really missed out on not getting one.The museum was small but very interesting. The lines are still running and the odor is very strong once you walk in. Museum itself is free but riding the cable cars does have a fee. It was kinda a shoot-in, shoot-out deal for me. I went through all the "exhibits" if you call it that and went around the lower floor and around the gift shop. Great for photos and learning the history of the cable car in the Bay Area.
author: Vikram V.

description:
As the daughter of an engineer, I had to make a stop here to see how the famous cable cars work. It's easy to get to, FREE, and educational. I loved it! 

You can make this as quick or as long of a stop as you want. Pop in just to see the cables in action or take more time to read each sign and get a better understanding about the history and mechanics of the system.

PS. It can get pretty warm inside so be prepared!
author: Kara H.

description: My first time here, and I can't add much else to what most everyone says:  It's free and it's wonderful.  If you are fascinated by the cable car system, then this place is a must-visit.
author: David S.

description:
My three year old daughter and I took a trip over to see this. She was excited to see all of the different parts. Her attention was short on each item, but she thought each piece was interesting.

The main floor shows the current machinery. When asking my daughter what she thought, she said, "It's like a factory." This in reference to the machines and machine shop area.

Additional items for up close inspection helped make this a good trip for her and me. We will be going again in the future as this will grow with her over time. We spent 45-60 minutes and scratched the surface for her educational value.

The only drawback is that being open to the machinery, it it noisy and hard to talk to each other. This con is offset by the price of admission. FREE!
author: Ryan A.

description:
Small, but free!  Definitely take the time to read everything and watch the whole documentary that is showing. It's fascinating how there are literally miles and miles of cable running through the city to operate the 4 cable car lines.

Bring a couple quarters to watch some of the old nickelodeon machines too!

I spent a bit of time just staring that the machinery that's both upstairs and downstairs. The lower parts seemed straight out of some futuristic underground steampunk movie.
author: Ryan H.

description: A nice little museum to check out during your cable car experience. All sorts of artifacts from the past and present. Was pretty cool to get up close to some of the machinery they use to control the cars on the street, as well as get a first hand look at the cables and motors that actually propel the cars through San Francisco. When you first enter the building, go to the right to check out the museum and store, however on your way out, make sure you go to the left, downstairs, to check out some of the inner workings of how the cables above are fed into the streets. Oh, and do take a moment to watch the video they have playing but in the back, not only does it give a good narrative tour of everything else you've seen in the museum, it's also quite funny to watch and see all the retro cars, outfits, and hair styles from the mid 1980s when it was produced.  Well worth a stop, will probably take you 30-45 minutes to work your way through.  Just make sure you buy the all day Muni pass, if you pay per ride, you'll have to spend another $7 to get back on another cable car.
author: Mike W.

description:
A little museum where you can actually see the working cables pulling the cable cars!

Admission is free, but drop a few dollars to support this museum if you can. It's a great testament to the city's history, and a fun little spot to check out if you're visiting.
author: Angelica K.

description:
Came across this place while on a jog. Not only was I excited because of my affection for museums, but it's FREE admission! Double WIN. 

It's not huge and there isn't a ton to look at, but for what it's worth, it's a cute little museum and definitely a place to spend a good 30-45 minutes at. 

For those of you with children (or is a child at heart) they have a trolley bell for you to ring too. :)
author: Michelle C.

description:
If this place ever gets shut down, I'm going to be pissed.

The bf and I are visiting SF together for the first time.  This means doing all the tourist-y things, posing in front of tourist-y places, and eating all tourist-y stuff.

Cable cars are definitely iconic of SF.  Which means I had to drag his ass up and down and up and down and down and up and down the SF hills to get here when we walked.

We got here around 5 minutes before 10am.  Because the museum opens 10am-6pm everyday (at free admission!), I asked him if we could wait for it to open, which he begrudgingly accepted.  After he was further annoyed by the people smoking, the museum finally opened, and we went immediately upstairs.  Or, I went upstairs and he followed me....into seeing all the cable lines.

Love at first sight, I tell you.  Bf was completely shocked and mesmerized by the fact that he was standing above the actual power house for the cable cars.  We actually both thought it was just a museum for the cable cars, but not that it was a true functioning building with a very important purpose.  Needless to say, very cool.  It can get a bit loud if you're not used to it, but it's just a loud hum.  You can see some of the employees in the back right-corner, doing their magic in either fixing or constructing parts for the cable cars.

On the left-hand corner of the building, you can sit down and watch a video on how the cable cars function, and a bit of the history.  All along the walls, you'll find news articles of when the cable cars were about to be eradicated.  You'll find a few cases with bus tokens, coin changers, and other small memorabilia.  One of the items that breaks my heart is a little memorial for 3 dogs that served the cable cars until their dying day.  They had a tragic end, as burglars poisoned them, and they basically died in the line of duty.  =(  Why isn't there any sort of souvenirs for these puppies, or something that would allow tourists to put in money to help support a local pet charity (SF SPCA?).  The story of the 3 dogs made me sad...

The gift shop isn't bad.  Lots of small little nifty items.  There are even bells that you can purchase to ring them (I think a few people actually try and use it as their doorbell).  Service is okay, but I can understand if they're grumpy because they hear a loud hum all day that they can't block out, and there's no real air conditioning. 

They have a penny machine, if you're looking for a cheap souvenir for the kiddies!
author: Grace C.

description: What a cute little museum! Of course I had to come here on my touristy trip to SF. It has several historic cable cars (along with signs not to board them :P), photographs, mechanical displays, and memorabilia. It also is the home to all the machinery that is actually keeping the cable cars running at this very moment. You can see the cables that are moving the cable cars in real time... it's pretty cool! While the museum is pretty small, you can still learn a lot about cable cars there. They also have a gift shop and a cable car seat that you can pose in. Best part is... it's free! Worth a visit for sure :)
author: Esther K.

description:
Its a quite small museum, but for those like me who love technical and historical stuff,  its a great place to be. you cant miss it.

you will find that its not only a museum,  its the real deal. the motors and workshop for the cable cars are in there and fully operational.

i loved it.
author: Carlos V.

description: Free admission! This museum offers an amazing look into an important part of San Francisco history. The Cable Car Museum teaches you the history and the mechanics of how the cars are run. On the lower level, you can see the wheels that actually power the four remaining cable car lines that exist, and old cable cars to admire.  Parts of cable cars are there for you to look at, and if you look outside, you a cable car runs by the museum. There are restrooms inside, as well as a fun gift shop. We spent about an hour there but I like to read all the signs. If you want to get an overall impression, you could be in and out in around 15 to 30 minutes. In the back on the top floor, there is an old film by General Electric about the cable cars. Now, we need to ride cable cars! $20 for a whole day. Yippee!
author: Melody H.

description: This was not one of my stops on the trip obv and I was dreading it all week. It turned out to be really fun. The place is small too so that helps. A full walk through will run you about an hour or so. What I though wa really great was the video in back. After watching that we got directly on a car outside. I felt like I knew what the operator was doing. lol
author: Alison H.
Dennis W.

description: Super cool and FREE museum of Cable Cars. Give you info, show you how the machinery works, and have cable cars from back in the years since they began! Also give you history. Staff seems a little watchful, however especially when you're around the cable cars. You can't get on them which is a draw back, but you can always get on the actual ones down by the tracks !
author: Jenny S.

description:
The Cable Car Museum is an interesting stop for your itinerary around San Francisco. (Riding on a cable car itself, however, is not...) 

The museum is a free (rare!) attraction that doubles as the central hub for the remaining cable cars in SF ... The layout of museum is quite serviceable but you will find it a bit loud due to the machinery that is working to keep the cars moving along the Streets of San Francisco (see what I did there?)

If you decide to ride on a cable car itself be warned ... it is a bit more expensive than you would think. It is a historical relic and a piece of Americana but you will be crowded in and it is packed asses to elbows. 

Enjoy the museum but skip the ride...
author: Ray B.

description: Very cool place.  A Mechanical Engineers dream place....... Very informative and you can actually see the cable lines really running the cable cars and which street each line is servicing.  There is a gift shop inside the museum.  Great for kids and adults alike.... And it's free with the option to leave donations.
author: Andrea P.

description:
Another hidden find of something that is FREE in SF! It's a forgotten item on every tourist's itinerary. Mostly because it's mostly unknown. 
The coolest part is see the actual cables and machinery operate LIVE! Super cool!!!!
author: David W.

description: If you're a history buff, a gearhead, an engineer or just love a good deal this place is for you.  Very educational and it's free.  Be sure to read most of the signs and/or descriptions...the more I read the more engaged I became.  And they have a public restroom...did I mention that it's free?
author: Kahai D.

description:
How is it that I've never known about this place?!?!?! It's amazing and free!  I'm not someone who's really into cars or trains, but it's just mesmerizing to watch the cables spin through the wheels.  I could probably just stand there, watching them for hours! Before going to the museum, I had no idea about the mechanics behind cable cars.  Now I know.

This is now added to my list of tourist attractions to bring out of town visitors too. They have a pretty large, extensive gift shop in the museum. Oh, and should I mention, there's a clean restroom, as well! Parking's probably not going to be too easy to come by, so just park a ways away, and walk.
author: Audrey C.

description:
If you're in San Francisco and you have the time, put the Cable Car Museum in your itinerary. It's a small museum situated near Chinatown. It's free and you'll have the chance to learn a lot about the history of the city and of the cable cars. What's also cool about this place -it's more than a museum, the tracks you'll see near the entrance still keep the cable cars running in the city. So, you really get to see how the cable cars work. Although we didn't have great experiences running in the cable cars, we still have a soft spot for them, since they're so unique of the city by the bay.  
They have a nice gift shop. Great little museum to check out, learn and take a break from walking up and down those cool steep streets!
author: Jo S.

description: My husband and I had so much fun visiting the museum!! It is self-paced, so you don't feel hurried through it. Free admission with an optional donation, which we gladly gave. It is fun and educational, not only about the cable car history, but about San Francisco as well. Pencil this in to your plans when you visit the area!!
author: Anj L.

description: Omg had no idea this was here! Happy accident stumbling by. Holy shit this is where all the cables get pulled?! Mindblown. Gift store and able to see the cable wheels spinning. Pretty cool.
author: Angela L.

description: Small, compact museum that is full of information about cable cars and the role they played in early San Francisco.  Great spot for anyone interested in early San Francisco history or how transportation grows cities.
author: Alan H.

description: This place is the bee's knees.  Here, you get to see the ACTUAL wheels that turn the entire cable car system in San Francisco.  Like literally, you walk in and there are the giant wheels powering the cable cars... live... so cool!  Add in a dash of history, and a pinch of science, and you have the best free touristy location in this city.  I can't recommend this more for both real kids and grown up kids alike.  Keep in mind, there's not a ton to see here, so it's really just the cable running wheels, and a handful of pictures painting the story of the cable car system, with a retired cable car, and a quaint gift shop...but totally worth seeing... and it's free.
author: Scott B.

description: Really a great stop to check out the history of the cable car. Dosn't take more than an hour to see and read everything, and while the exhibits are interesting and nostalgic, the real fun comes from watching the cables and giant wheels that pull and connect every car in all of San Francisco all at once. Fascinating for both kids and adults and well worth a drop-in.
author: Jeff L.

description: It's free but it's loud if you have little ones. Very interesting to learn the history and see how the Cable Cars work!!
author: Jess H.

description: This place is so great!!! It's a small museum filled with plenty of facts and visuals. They show you how the cable cars run and the equipment/machinery that moves all the cars. It's something fun to do in the city when you have some time. Its great for kids, I took my 4 year old and she loved it. She enjoyed seeing the big machinery and the original cable cars. They have a bell that's like the ones they use on the cable cars and she had a blast ringing it and pretending she was in charge. Had a great time overall and was really educational.
author: Stephanie M.

description: Best part of the museum was that it was free. Not sure if it's just that my personal likings didn't agree with this place but I was just very disinterested. By the reviews I was for sure we would enjoy this place. However, both me and my mate agreed that this place was pretty boring. There was one wall that caught my attention for all of 5 minutes but even trying to read (which I normally love to do) was a drag here. Sorry I definitely wouldn't recommend this place nor would I visit again.
author: Yanni B.

description:
Great experience. Highly recommend. It took me and my husband about an hour- 1 1/2 hours to walk the whole thing. It's really interesting to learn about the history of the city. You can also see the mechanics of the cables and this is fascinating for anyone!
And it's FREE!
author: Stefanie R.

description:
I have been coming to the Cable Car Museum for many years, before Yelp even existed.  If you want to learn about how the Cable Cars work and a little San Francisco history, this is the place!  It is a noisy place though.  If you have small children who are sensitive to loud noises, they will not like this place.

From upstairs you can look down and see the huge wheels which propel the steel cables underneath the streets of San Francisco and pull the Cable Cars along.  There is also a gift shop.  I avoid the touristy junk and look for the historical items.  You can buy slices of an actual steel Cable Car cable, old tokens and other memorabilia. 

There are also several ancient cable cars you can look at, but not sit in.  At the far end there is a video about the Cable Cars on an endless loop.  It's not too long, and worth watching.

Don't forget to head downstairs before you leave so you can see the machinery operating below ground level.

Best of all, this museum is free!
author: The Bottomless Pi T.

description: Fantastic museum, especially if you like cable car history. Fun for a short little look. However there could be more content. All and all a fun but short experience.
author: Ethan P.

description:
SF is a wonderful place for walking. 

Along the way, you might bump into some odd spectacles - for example, the strange man with cow ears yelling, "I'M THE BOSS!" at nobody in particular. 

But if you're really lucky, you might stumble into a free museum.

After taking the cable cars up and down SF's steep hills, it's interesting to learn about their history, creators, and moving parts. This museum is not the most spectacular - I wouldn't even call it a destination, unless you're really into engineering - but it's definitely cool to see how the cable cars work. You can actually watch the wheels turn as they pull the cars around the city in a seamless loop. The museum is the resting spot for all cable cars, where they come to roost from 1am-6am, where maintenance is done on the cable lines and the cars themselves. There's something about not taking things for granted that makes this museum worth visiting. 

Thank you, cable cars, for staying attached to the cables and not flying down Lombard street like runaway trains.
author: Ray J.

description: I recommend visiting the museum first, before taking a ride on a Cable Car. We noticed that the lines at Powell are very long. So it's worth planning the ride in the other direction, starting at the Bay and arriving at Powell.
author: Annelies B.

description:
Wow! I have never seen anything so amazing. The clear walls showing the cables underneath the street are fascinating. 

- Allie, age 8

It's a pretty cool little place. Doesn't take too long, so it's great for kids. And it's free! It's also a good spot to hitch a ride on the cable cars (as opposed to waiting in line at the termini...)

- Chris, a little older than 8
author: Chris C.

description:
Free, fun, educational. 

There is also a gift shop.

We stopped by here as part of a self-guided walking/stairing tour of SF. We must have walked over 5mi and up/down countless SF streets with stairs/steps.

(Review drafted 04/22/13)
author: qirk z.

description: This museum is very interesting, it's explains you since the beginning the history of the cable car in San Francisco until today. You got to see the first cable car back in 1873, many historical pictures and as well the engines and winding wheels who pulls the cables. Amazing and all this for free ! You should check it out !
author: Julien F.

description: So cool! You never really think about the "Cable,' part in Cable car, but the museum makes it really clear. A must stop in SF.
author: Greg F.

description:
The Cable Car Museum

The Cable Car Museum is located San Francisco, on Mason and Washington Streets.  Here at the museum you will see the history of Cable Cars and the various companies that were involved with bringing and developing the Cable Car Systems to San Francisco.  It's a very interesting museum.  This was how a part of the mass transportation started in the early years before buses.

Basically what they have developed is an underground cable system that pulls each cable car through the streets of San Francisco.  How this is done is exhibited at the museum with plenty of details....(something to be appreciative of....we've come a long way since the Cable Car).

Today's Cable Car can carry an average of 60 passengers.  Each cars can weight 15,500 lbs. And are 27' 6" long (Powel and Hyde Cable Cars and Powel and Mason Cable Cars).  The California line Cable cars are 16,800 lbs. And 30' 3" long.  The weight of the car does not include passengers and operators.  So the cable system that you see at the Cable Car Museum is a fully operational one.  You will see the cables leading into the streets of San Francisco.  
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7HUGEQhazzWHEHOuF9eSdQ?select=Lo3Ns6ut_M7-igAvSvPbnA
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7HUGEQhazzWHEHOuF9eSdQ?select=7a1Vb3oOw1UjNGz2x-tTGw

This system is required to pull a certain amount (not sure of the exact numbers) cable cars and passengers daily through out San Francisco.  Up the hill, down the hill and it's straight away.  You'll see the major components of a cable car.  

One of the most important part of the cable car is "The Grip".
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7HUGEQhazzWHEHOuF9eSdQ?select=6gNQ1jVDVYHiHhPKZx2Sdg
The grip is required to grab the cable below the streets and pull the cable cars through the railroad tracks.  The "Cable" travels at a constant 9.5mph and the gripman (operator) uses the grip to pull the car at a desire speed between 0 and 9.5 mph.  They also use the cable as a control method of breaking when going downhill so the car is not out of control and makes it easy to stop at slower speeds.  Parts on the grip usually last for 3 to 4 days and then requires maintenance...so some times you'll see mechanics changing out the grip for a new one.  

Each cable car has 2 truck that it sit on.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/7HUGEQhazzWHEHOuF9eSdQ?select=P6CVXAsyqHamZxpLT5_ikQ
A "truck" consist of 4 wheels that runs on the Cable Car Tracks and is required to hold the payload of the body of the cable car and it's passengers and operators.  Also on the truck is a brake system that is controlled from the body of the cars....front and back.  

So...you have "The Grip", "Brakes", "Trucks" and of course the emergency brakes.  The emergency brake is a lever on the Cable Car that when engaged will cause the car to come to a sudden stop.

I've posted some pictures of their payment methods, tokens, transfers, coin changer, and some of the operators badges.

These are some of the basic of how today's cable car works.  To see the whole system and how it was developed is what is very interesting to see at the Cable Car Museum.  
It's free, they are open from 10am to 5pm daily (double check before going).  
It's clean.
It's fun and enjoyable.
Good for kids and family.
No pushy people trying to sell you anything.
Go as you please and leave with additional knowledge if you don't already know about the Cable Car System.
No food is served.
Bathrooms are in the back.
A 5 star worthy trip.
author: Alan L.

description: First of all, it's good exercise to walk there from the nearby hotels.  Second, admission is free.  Although the museum is small, it's worth visiting as it provides valuable interesting info.  I had no idea that this place powers all the cable cars.  A word of caution - it's hot in there.
author: Ross W.

description: Great local hidden gem!  If you are staying on Nob Hill or visiting North Beach or Chinatown, the Cable Car Museum is a must visit.  It's an actual working museum and one can hear the gears working even before you step into the door.  The large turning wheels show what goes on beneath the ground.  Videos and memorabilia help tell the story and history of the famous cable cars...including the impact of the 1906 earthquake. Kitchsy fun like sitting in old car chairs and old fashioned 25-cent video viewers offer short video views of the  earthquake also add to the fun.  The best part?  IT'S FREE! (But leave a small donation as its a non profit run location)
author: Mitzi A.

description: Since it is a free museum there isn't anything to complain about. It's really impressive to see the big motors run and powering the cable cars. There is also a nice gift shop for some great souvenirs
author: Patrick W.

description:
This is a must visit place if you have any interest at all in this unique piece of California history. Cable cars are simply amazing and a great way to get around the hilly parts of San Francisco. I only wish it was not six dollars each way as that is quite pricey. 

I was shocked that admission was free and surely I donated to keep this great museum alive. Museums should all be free to the public but that's another story. 

This is also great for kids and even my seven-year-old was interested.
author: Bergen E.

description:
This is more than a museum, it's the actual plant that powers the cable cars! And it's free!

Just wanted to get that out first, in case you're skimming.

I highly recommend this place. It's amazing to see the machines that are pulling the cable cars all around town. There's also cool old photos and historical information like you might find in normal museums. Did I mention it's free? If you're in the neighborhood, it's worth popping in for at least 10 minutes.
author: John B.

description:
We are from the Bay Area and this is the first time that we visit the Cable Car Museum.

The museum is very small.  Basically, it has one main floor and a small basement.  It is actually an operational cable car gear and engine area!!!  You can see the gears spinning and pulling the cables.  You can see old cable cars from eons ago.  You also get to view the history thru the years and how the cable car system works.  It's very educational for both adults and kids of all ages.

Parking, in general in San Francisco, is terrible as usual.
author: Mike Y.

description: Very informative and professional museum.  Learned a lot.  Didn't spend more than an hour there, but I enjoyed it. Pair it with a cable car ride and it is worth it.
author: Mark B.

description: Great place to visit. You get to learn about the San Francisco cable car history and how they work. All cable cars line lead to the museum.
author: Raymond S.

description:
