The best thing going for this place is the free admission. I was a little disappointed by the contents in this museum. Its not a very big building and there is some history to it, but it wasn't what I was expecting.

When you walk in you can go downstair to view the underground cogs operating the cables that pull the cable cars. There are some signs and placards that you could read to get information about the origins of the first street cars in San Francisco. Upstairs it gets a little more touristy with the coin-operated machines that depict the 1906 earthquake, the gift shop and the replica cable cars that you can get your picture taken. There is also a large viewing area where you can see the actual cables coming and leaving the building and their corresponding lines. 

It's a good place to burn an hour, but keep your expectations low.
author: Khris S.

description:
For those with even the slightest curiosity of how mechanical things work, this museum will be sheer pleasure.  You'll see the machines that actually pull the cable that runs day and night.

Most of us don't know that the cable is running all the time.  What is happening is that the "cars" are grabbing on to that moving cable and being pulled.  When they want to stop they simply release from the moving cable.

Great historical pieces in here.  Check it out!
author: Stephen H.

description:
What a great FREE museum!

I was under the impression this was just going to be an informational museum, but it's actually the building that powers the SF Cable Cars!! As you walk inside you definitely notice some loud machine noises, and when you walk up the stairs you find out why. There are twelve huge wheels rotating and pulling the cables that are connected to the cable cars that are running on the street. The informational displays are very informative and are definitely worth reading; they help you understand how the cable car system runs.

As you move farther along there is more information about the history of the cable cars; I liked the part covering the time period when some people wanted to get rid of the cable cars and problems ensued. Thank goodness the cars are still around! There is a gift shop near the back which isn't much to see, and the restrooms are located near there as well. 

Definitely come check this museum out if you have time! It's very interesting and you don't have to pay (although donations are appreciated) =D
author: Sam F.

description:
Best museum to take out of towners to see... its free, its small & it makes sense of the cable cars you so often hear cranking around town!!

 A gem of a spot!!
author: Kristy B.

description:
This place is just a great museum. You get to see the inner workings of the cable cars in the city, which are still working thanks to these guys.

You can learn a ton of history about the city and cable cars and you can take some pictures with old cable cars, all for free.

A totally cool and free thing to do.
author: Luis D.

description:
Great FREE museum.  Very interesting, good displays, fascinating to watch the actual cables drive the cars. The movie is a little outdated and groovy but it made it fun to watch.

I highly recommend a visit to this museum.
author: Drew M.

description:
A perfect noisy, stinky and charming slice of San Francisco history.  Definitely worth a trip whether you are a tourist or local.  You can easily be in and out in about an hour. 

Here's a tip to avoid the inevitable headache of trying to find parking -- take a cable car to the Cable Car Museum!
author: Emily J.

description:
Fun.

Watching the huge wheels go round and round is somewhat dizzying but it is very cool to see what keeps the SF cable cars humming.  

Visitors and residents alike should check out the cable car museum. There is also a collection of SF memorabilia that is interesting with a special focus on the 1906 quake.
author: Elyn Z.

description: This is a great stop on any tour of San Francisco, you can see all the machinery used to pull the cable cars up & down the hills, sit in a car (not crowded, but not moving), and learn plenty of history about the cars and the city. A pretty inexpensive stop and worth it, especially if you're a fan of history or the cable cars.
author: Spencer S.

description:
My dad took my brother and me here today. I thought it is pretty cool to see how cable cars work. 

It is simple basic and nice in there. The best of all it opens daily and it's free to get in. I'm not a tourist I come to San Francisco often. I'm glad my dad had the chance to take his two kids here.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
If you complain one second about this place you have no soul so just go away.

Cable Car Museum is FREE.  But they take donations so if you are so inclined drop a few dollars in the box.

It is self guided.  Basically a large room with scattered history, story boards and trolley car paraphernalia.  The best part is that in the middle of the warehouse are the actual spinning wheels that run the cable cars.  Engineering buffs will love reading about how this is constructed and maintained.  People this is the only cable car system still in use in the entire world!!
author: Heather F.

description:
I suffer from an acute case of train exhaustion. Raising two boys means that I've visited almost every train museum on the West Coast. At least is feels that way. Happily they are long past that stage, but this still seemed like a good, quick stop in between other activities in San Francisco.

It is really more of a diversion than a destination. And it is FREE so there is no obligation to stay and 'get your money's worth'.

There are certainly things to see, including the active cable lines, but not much to do. We enjoyed taking family photos sitting in the modified rail car near the entrance, but most of the other displays involve reading about the history of cable cars. This didn't hold the kids' attention for long.

One of the interesting facts is that even though time marches on, little has changed regarding the care and maintenance of the rail cars. For example, it takes a group of men hours to manually splice and repair a section of cable. All of this done during the wee hours of the morning when the cable cars aren't running. Looking at the photos, the employees look like miners navigating the subterranean depths of the city. Glad I don't have their job.

Cable cars are one of the great symbols of San Francisco. Worth a visit to learn about the history if you have time, but I wouldn't go out of your way unless you have a train or history nut in tow.
author: Jen K.

description:
There are so many different things to see and do in San Francisco, most of which involved shoveling food into your mouths, but the Cable Car Museum is definitely a must-see. 

There is no admission charge and you're free to walk around the museum unguided where you can view one of the first cable cars placed in service, the inner workings and gears of these cars but most impressive is the actual cable car pulley system in operation.
author: Garran C.

description: Clang, clang, clang  goes the trolley...ring, ring, ring goes the bell...Free, informative & interesting.  The historical photos & stories were insightful.  Amazing the technology/tradition is still alive & kicking - no electicity needed.  Charming draw of SF.  Although the smell of grease can be overwhelming.
author: Kim S.

description:
The Cable Car Museum provides some necessary education for any San Franciscan who truly wants to be called a local. Free admission is a plus.

The museum is also the main hub for all the cable car lines in the city. You can see the actual sheaves that pull the cables for each line. It's pretty amazing to watch it in-person. You learn all of the mechanics that go into operating the cable cars.

The whole time you're there, the cable cars come swooping around the corner outside - pretty awesome context. 

I enjoyed discovering all the lines that existed before the 1906 earthquake. Cable cars used to run the city! 

My one criticism is that the museum is stuffy and I swear it smells carcinogenic. I'm also paranoid, though. It's a risk I'm willing to take - such a cool place!
author: Alyssa W.

description:
Free!
Interesting facts!
Bathrooms!
author: Sarah C.

description:
Yay for free!

I spent about half an hour learning more about cable cars than I ever wanted to know.  The reason that I took off 1 star is because I'm lazy and I don't like to read.  This museum had too many displays to read. I wish it was more hands on.

Cable cars are an important part of SF's history and locals and visitors alike should give this little museum a visit.
author: Yi Z.

description:
This is such a gem, a free and educational experience that every visitor to San Francisco should avail themselves of. 

I dragged my companion here with promises of enlightenment as to the finer points of the workings of the cable car system, and she was not disappointed with the experience. 

This is a great place to bring the kids, to gawk at the huge sheaves and cables endlessly turning in the area below the main level of the museum. Buy the kiddies -- or yourself -- a souvenir from the museum shop, and get your geek on looking at the inner mechanics of the levers that grip and release the cable that pulls the cars up San Francisco's steep slopes. Marvel at how difficult it must have been to traverse these hills when they were unpaved and muddy, and how this elegantly simple system transformed the city.
author: Angela L.

description:
It's actually really interesting. The history of the Cable car  doesn't sound it interesting does it? So imagine my pleasant surprise.

I just love how they laid out this museum. It is really easy to take every in and all the old artifacts or  models of cable cars are easy to see. It's not too much information at once, which allows the story behind its legacy easy to understand. 

My favorite part is the history wall, where there are newspaper clipping, old black and white photographs, and quotes from people back in the day. The day of the 1906 earthquake was a nightmare, but it is cool to see, despite the bad luck, the public cared about the cable car to keep it around to even this day.

I mean, imagine the hills of San Francisco without its loveable Cable car!
author: Alice C.

description: Fun and Free and Full of Cable Car trivia, history and mechanics. We are so glad we stopped by for a look!
author: Jami N.

description: It's pretty easy to get here. Just take the Bart to Telegraph and the cable care station is right there. There will probably be a line. I suggest going on a weekday. The cable car goes up to hill right to the museum. The conductor will tell you when to get off. It's very interesting and historical. It's a small museum, but there is a lot to learn here. It's neat looking down into the turning rotors that movie the cars about the city. The gift shop was huge and the staff was very nice. We went on a Saturday and it was incredible crowded, so as I said, go on a weekday. This is on my list of "Best Museums in the Bay Area"
author: Liz C.

description:
This is a must visit place in SF. Amazing that how they still run this technology in todays world. SF have preserved this charm of the city. I am really not sure - how many people knows how cable car runs? its interesting. You gotta check this out. Its a free admission and really kool.
When you are riding on cable car and if you smell something burning...dont worry those are wooden brakes that they still use..its a smell of their wear and tear..which is replaced every 3 days...there are more fun facts. you will like it!
author: Rasesh P.

description: Well thought out museum. Very spacious and easy to navigate. The actual cable drives are operating in front of your eyes and can be observed in detail from the mezzanine/museum. The history of the cable cars are explained in intricate detail as well as the mechanical operations of the cable car system. An exciting museum for a mechanical engineer.
author: Ira P.

description:
An amusing little place. Interesting facts and free! (Which is always nice in SF)

Filing in space. Filing in space.  Filing in space. Blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah.
author: Kirby H.

description:
I will keep this short but sweet. As a bay area native and having gone to San Francisco my entire life, this is one of the best keet secrets ever. I actually miss this place.

I have been all over the world, to over 20 countries...I've seen the earths amazing places, and wonders like the Panama Canal. When you visit this working museum, you realize how awesome the industrial age really was, you realize how crazy San Francisco was and still is.....this place is nutty!

When I say it's a "working museum" I MEAN the cable wheels are right there in your face spinning away PULLING THE CABLE CARS UP AND DOWN THOSE ICONIC STREETS. Do not miss this place, it is awesome, I'm from here and I never get tired of this place, your jaw will hit the deck when you see this mechanical wonder.
author: Joe S.

description: Awesome place to visit during our stay in San Fran! Love that it was free since the expenses were adding up a lot. Lots of cool information on the cable cars and how they operate. It was so interesting! A must-visit. The staff was friendly as well.
author: Kirsten N.

description: Really neat to see the cable car station in action! A must stop if you are in town as a tourist. They have a good souvenir shop and great views from the trolley hub location.
author: Jeff V.

description:
Love this place and so do our kids. It was fun to see the actual cables and pulleys that move the trolleys along the tracks and to discover just how it all works! The first time we visited, the Powell lines were down and we saw a crew working to replace the problematic section of cable! 

Learned a lot about both SF and cable car history. Can't beat the price either. Definitely worth a visit!
author: C C.

description: I love this museum! It is packed with a lot of histories of SF since the gold rush and along the natural disasters that happened here years ago. It is a must see with free admission but donation is appreciated.
author: Sweetie Joanna A.

description: Cute little museum with all kinds of facts about the history and workings of the cable car system in SF. Aside from all the cool displays and whatnot, you get to see how the cables really work, considering you're right on top of where all the cables get spun--amazing. It's also FREE (I did throw in a couple of bucks)! My favorite was ringing the cable car bell, tee hee!
author: Steph H.

description: Cool info on San Francisco cable car history. It's neat to see the cables downstairs still working.
author: Monica S.

description:
OK. First of all: it's FREE!

Then you walk in. Wow. So much history packed into a relatively small area. The entire museum all on one level with the lower level containing the giant engines and wheels that pull the actual cables (which really is an amazing site).

Real cable cars from the past (some of which you can actually board) and beautifully laid out. I just wish my wife and I had more time to walk through!

And did I mention it's FREE?!? Seriously. Wow.
author: Michael Anthony C.

description: Lot of history and cool information here whether you're into public transit or not.
author: Sarah P.

description: For those who thought this place was boring, guess what? It's free, stop complaining. My wife and I had a great time. We got to learn all about the cable cars we were riding all week. You get to see all the cables running and learn about what it takes to maintain them. There is even a gift shop that has some nice things for sale. If you're there before they open, wait across the street at the cafe, that's a nice place too.
author: Gelacio V.

description:
Most San Franciscans think this is a tourist trap... how wrong! The Cable Car Museum is such a jewel. The only museum I have ever visited that doesn't infuse an ounce of boredom in me. As a matter of fact, I have been there 5 times already and I will keep on going there.
This place is an experience. It is not only filled with historic machines, pictures and facts about this beautiful city, it is also an actual factory. You can see the old engines of the 3 cable car lines running through the city. You hear them LOUDLY. You smell them STRONGLY. You see people working HARD on these cables. Visiting the cable car museum is an awakening of the senses.
It is a travel to a past that is still present and embodies the best of San Francisco.

Thank you so much to the City for opening this place to all and for free.
author: Annabelle G.

description: Very cool place and free! Interesting to see how the cable cars work. Usually I go quickly through museums but I took my time here and enjoyed watching the machinery and reading the history.
author: Kathleen B.

description: How is it that I've lived here for 7 years and never checked out this gem?! Finally made it to the museum today, touring my dad around town, figuring he'd like it. I was amazed at the rich historical information that was presented, and the fact that this is actually the hub for the cables! A must see, especially if you've lived here for ages and never checked it out!
author: Christine K.

description:
Jump on the Trolley and head over to this quaint little museum. 

The best part is that its actually the working 'engine' of the cable cars that run through parts of SF. You can see the giant wheels pulling the cables, and read about how they work. There's also a bit of info on the effects the big earthquake and fires had on the evolution of this transit system.
We happily poked around for a half hour or so, hit the gift shop for the obligatory shot glasses for my roommates, then hopped right back on the trolley to ride to the Aquarium. 
On a side note; if you jump on the Trolley, make sure you get on and off a few stops before the beginning or end. It seems that's when the conductors are most likely to collect for the rides. Out of our three trips on the cable Cars, we only paid once. (if you don't want to cheat the system, you can also get an $11 ride all day pass).
author: David M.

description:
Talk about hands on, as close as you can get to feeling like a conductor without actually getting a degree in engineering - this museum showcases everything interesting about the San Francisco Cable Car, as well as displaying actual working parts of the system. You can go downstairs and see what's happenin' under the street of San Francisco. It's pretty amazing.
Complete with video, photos, and signage from back in the day, I'd say it was as close to a school field trip as I was going to get.

And it's free...that's right F-R-E-E!
author: Sherri K.

description: Don't go to San Fran and skip the Cable Car Museum. It is free, it is convenient, and it will give you great context for how San Fran became the city it is today. After hiking around the city we had planned on visiting the museum and we were very happy that we did. It is a relatively small museum but anyone who is interested in San Fran, mechanics, or even just curious as to how the heck the city functions, give the cable car museum 60 minutes of your time.
author: Matt C.

description:
FANTASTIC time filler, and it's FREE!  Bring the parents, Amaze the kids!  just stand and be mesmerized by those little cables that are as you stand witness, pulling the famed cable cars of people all around The City.  It's the much less glamorous but no less interesting facet of one of the most identifiable symbols of the eternal City by the Bay.  

LOVED the time i spent here, and would absolutely come back to swing through again, i really enjoyed just watching the cables and the men who work on them.

NOTE... when you go upstairs, you'll find a railing with a gate under it which encircles the entire "open" area over the cables, so you can watch the goings on.  No matter how tempted you are, don't put your knee or any other body part through the slats in the fencing under the rail.. or allow your children to do so... how do i know this?

I got stuck. 

yep.  I got STUCK.  and my most awesome souvenir this trip was the MASSIVE bruises on both sides of my left leg, including the top front of my thigh.  

Shhhhhh... I didn't tell anyone and just tore myself out and limped away due to my outstanding personal embarrassment... but just an FYI.... look for the benches scattered about if you want to sit or lean.  (duh!)

Just a word of caution from Lady Pumpfat (and apparently, knee fat)

oh and don't miss the giftstore for your standard 'Frisco Kitsch!!!!!
author: Rachel C.

description: So cool!  Be sure to go downstairs to see the cable system up close.
author: Rich V.

description:
I didn't even know this place existed! I ran in, looking for a bathroom. It was cool to see the mechanics behind a cable car. I'll have to come back since I didn't get to actually check everything out.

The cable car drivers (I think they are cable car drivers...) who sit out in front are a bit rude.
author: Margaret R.

description: Fascinating !!!! You are going to get really educated about the secrets of this fun way of going around :) totally great for family time and the engineer in you :)
author: Barbara A.

description: It's free, it shows you how these cool things run. It's an informative place to drop in for 10 minutes and see what the humming noise below the city streets are. Also there's a pretty clean bathroom inside.
author: Tay T.

description: Great FREE way to learn about one of San Francisco's most historic modes of transportation. Working mechanics, signage, gift shop, and plenty of information make this a fun way to understand the cable car concept. Walking distance from Financial District, although up a pretty steep hill. Wear your comfy shoes! Don't miss this!
author: Lisa L.

description:
Free admission. It's not exactly like the academy of sciences or the exploratorium but the cable car museum has its own charm. Its basically the cable car barn with exhibits on the history of cable cars in San Francisco. 

From the main floor, you can see the  large figure eight pulleys with the cables running through, something that I thought was really cool. You see a lot of artifacts of the early cable car models up to recent photographs of events significant to the cable cars evolution through history. If you travel downstairs, I personally think this room is the best, the underground viewing room. Such a fascinating sight to see. The tilted wheels whirring cables around pulling the cable cars running throughout the city above ground. 

You should check this out. It's free! Simple as that.
author: Alex T.

description: Free! This is one of the most interesting free museums I have been too. You can learn all about how the cable car system works. The view of the cable pulley's is extremely interesting. One look will change your whole thought process on how the cable cars work. Did I mention it is free?!!!
author: Danny B.

description:
For a free museum this place is really great. They have nice displays, interesting information and you get to see the actual hub for the cable cars. It's really a very interesting peak into the history of San Francisco and how the cable cars are still operating today.

Of course to make our visit complete we rode a cable car to the museum, which i also recommend.

This place is a great, free way to spend a couple hours on a lazy afternoon.
author: Holly R.

description: A great informative museum.  I had no idea on the details how the cable cars worked, never really thought about it.  It's free, just go.
author: Kazuo O.

description: Really interesting museum with heaps of history about the cable cars. It's great being able to look over the edge and see the big wheels and cables moving. It's quite loud but it adds to the interest of the museum! The museum gives a great insight into the history of San Francisco and why the cable cars have become so important to the city.
author: Lauren T.

description:
Let's do a San Francisco math problem:

    (1)Museum 
+ (1873)Oldest Cable Car in the World 
+ Actual Place That Makes the Cables Turn for the Entire City 
+ Cool Facts Posted Everywhere 
+ (42)Photo Opportunities 
+ (5)Pounds Lost Walking To and From Powell Station 
+ (16.95)Gift Shop with books about old SF 
+ (.25)Footage of the 1906 earthquake 
+ (0.00)Admission Price

 = THE AMAZING ADVENTURES OF THE CABLE CAR MUSEUM
author: Jared S.

description:
This is a must see if you're in SF, especially if you're in engineer or some one that likes to see how things work.  And it's free!

It's small and humid, but this is (one of) the working backbones of the cable cars. The top level, you can see the engines working with pulley and cable systems. There are lots of description to explain how they work. My only complaint is that there was the same description everywhere, but written by different people. I wish there was more consistency. 

There are old cable cars on display, and an old blueprint of the actual cable mechanism to show you how it worked. 

On the walls are old photos of back when the cable car first started. Most interesting was on the back wall and the story of how the Cable Car was meant to be dismantled, and how they saved it. 

Unfortunately, I spent too much time reading this, and EVEN THOUGH the place closes at 6pm, the video of the cable car turns off at 5:30pm. I find this ridiculous. We were sitting right there, and at 5:30, she prompted waddled over and turned it off. 

Also, the souvenir store, already started closing up, as they already covered half the stuff with a tarp. It was only 5:30, and they close at 6!
author: Laura C T.

description:
This museum was a bit of a surprise. Just beyond Chinatown (up some more steep hills), it is not so much a museum as the main operating station for the entire cable car network, with 60% of the museum consisting of the actual cable machines themselves and the machine shop.

The museum is unique in all its noisy and smelly glory, showing you the inner workings of a one-of-a-kind public transport system, including the history of the network and the city and the evolution of the system from its origins to the modern iteration. Oh, and it's free, so stop in and see it.

The only downside, if there is such a thing, is that it is a rather short visit and that it may not be ideal for small children and anyone not interested in mechanics.

Overall, a very nice visit, and a good spot to catch the cable car back to either downtown or Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Jan T.

description:
This place proves that when Homer Simpson is wrong when he says that anything ending in eum can't be any fun. Not only a museum but it is where work is being done and it's free.
 How do you get to the cable car museum? Take the cable car.
author: Thomas M.

description: Loved to see how the cable cars were run!  Awesome displays of historic pieces.  Definitely a must stop for a quick look around.  There is a small gift shop with nice finds.  The staff wasn't very helpful and bathrooms were a little dirty but other than that it was an interesting stop.
author: Krystal C.

description: I actually really liked this museum. You get to learn so much about the history of cable cars! The best part is, it's all free! It's amazing getting to know how the system works and operates. There's so many different things to discover and learn about cable cars, I don't think anyone should miss out on this.
author: Cathy M.

description:
I didn't realize this place even existed. Hit the nearby attractions button when I got to Chinatown and this place popped up as an option for something to do. Decided to walk over and check it out. The wheels turning the cables were hypnotic. It never occurred to me that there was a central place that controlled all of the different lines and that the system was so complex. 

The downstairs view into the tunnel was really cool. Also, it was free-way awesome!!!
author: Lily K.

description: This is a fun place to pop by any time you're in the neighborhood.  I've lived in San Francisco for 4 years and have stopped in two or three times.  I can't believe there are fun things to do like this that are free to visitors!
author: Janelle C.

description: Love this place!  We always bring friends and family by here when they visit the bay and enjoy their amazement at how long these cables are and all the other interesting facts about them.  Very relaxing place too and I enjoy just a moment watching the wheels spin and cable passing by to gather my thoughts.
author: John F.

description: Free.  Short visit.  Interesting.  This is a quick way to understand the heart of the San Francisco cable car story.  May be a little noisy, because this is a Working museum, the cables are all powered from here.  Close to Chinatown
author: Marc L.

description:
Big wheels keep on turning. But instead of rolling down the river, they roll down the steep hills of San Francisco. You can see these big, electric-powered wheels in action as they move cable under the city streets at this museum. It's really a cool thing to see. There are other exhibits about how a cable car functions, public transportation in San Francisco, and a gift shop. The entire experience took 25 minutes.

If we didn't buy a Muni pass (at Walgreen's and not the Hyde turn-around), we probably wouldn't have come here. Although the cable cars go directly to the museum (because their cables are powered here), I wouldn't want to pay $6 a person to ride the cable car. Enduring the hour-long wait to get on the cable car only increased the frustration of getting to this museum.
author: Brian U.

description:
I was really amazed by how Cable Car was operated underground and its techniques..
Notice that this museum is very SMALL, took us around 30 mins to look through..
author: Bing G.

description: It's a look behind the scenes as to how the cable cars are built, maintained and the cable system that makes them run. The five electric motors move all of the city's cable cars around the hills at up to nine miles an hour from 6AM to 1AM. Any repairs or problems to the cables or machinery is done after those hours. Fascinating and it is free. Best way to get there? The cable car!
author: George C.

description:
Went there today for the first time ever.  They had the oldest cable car in the world there from the 1800s.  I got to ring the bell for the cable car.  This place is a real working cable car cable pulling station.  These huge wheels spin and it's really a trip.  

On top of that it's free.  If you are riding the cable car it will drop you right off in front of this building.  No admission charge!  If you love SF and you love cable cars you should go.
author: Cynthia B.

description: As a disclaimer, I only went because I ride by it every day on the cable car and I had nothing better to do that day. With that said, it wasn't that bad. I was always curious how the tourist traps that are the cable cars worked and this place answered all my questions. Did I mention it's FREE? I spent about 20 minutes there and felt satisfied by the things I learned. It's not the MOMA or anything but you should at least step inside and learn a little bit about these SF landmarks that are the cable cars.
author: Carlos A.

description: I live right around the block from this museum, and I am so glad I checked it out with some friends.  It really gives a thorough history of the cable car in SF (what a plight!) as well as some interesting information on SF history weaved in.  Getting to see the cables that connect the entire city was quite a treat.  Feel lucky that I live so close!
author: Mel G.

description:
SO COOL & FREE! 
This combination is hard to find in this city, so take advantage of it! You'll be amazed at the history of cable cars, the mechanics of it and seeing everything in action. Great gift shop too. Step out the door & you can hop right on. San Francisco at its finest.
author: Sara P.

description: I went on a run ad stumbled into this place. Perfect for the curious mind. Loved being in a 'working' museum. Worth the trip up the hill. Free. enjoyed it immensely.
author: Graham Y.

description: It was really cool something you should def see in SF. It's non-profit so do donate so this can stay around forever. Perfect for singles, couples and families!!!!
author: Dara T.

description:
Nice time filler...  and totally free. 

Ever wonder how the cable cars grab the cable?  You get your answer here.
Ever wonder where the cable gets its power?  You'll see it here.  

Great background and history of the system.  The kids loved ringing the bell.
author: Jeff G.

description: What a fantastic destination to visit with the whole family.  It is free to enter and provides truly one-of-a-kind access to the physical inner-workings of a mass transit system.  I thought I knew a lot about the history of street cars in San Francisco, but I learned so much more from the elegant and well laid out timelines on displayed here.  Very enjoyable stop along my route through the Bay Area this Spring!
author: Happy H.

description: You really can't give this place less than 5 stars simply because it's free. If you have no interest in SF history and you don't really care about cable cars then maybe this place isn't for you (and even then, just walk out). I enjoyed my time walking around and reading all the information that was displayed. I feel like this is an overlooked gem in the city because it's never too crowded. Stop by and learn something. My favorite part was seeing the giant cogs turning, pulling the cables. Pretty cool.
author: Tommy C.

description:
"Ding! Ding!" I think it was just cool to ring the bell that sits by itself as part of the museum. It's like getting to blow the air horn on a semi truck or whistle on a train locomotive. Just one of those childhood dreams of a Bay Area kid. The place is plain loud. It's an actual working place is why. You will be able to see the miles of actual cables that stretch under the streets of San Francisco. It's an engineering wonder.

It has tons of history about the cars as well as older models and a small gift shop inside. 

Finally, it's FREE! You are probably going to park on the street, so make sure that your wheels are turned the right way (downhill toward curb/uphill away from curb) and your parking break is on.
author: Brian A.

description:
Walking in here is literally like walking back in time... this (free) museum is located in and around the main power plant for San Francisco's cable car system... this is by far the coolest and unique feature of the place... actually seeing what makes the system work... if you are a mechanical kind of guy (gal) then seeing these giant motors and gear reductions doing their thing is totally worth stopping by here...

Also housed here are old cable cars from throughout the history of the system, and displays showcasing the secret (mechanical) life of the cable car, from the braking system, to the cable catchers, speed control and all sorts of mechanical oddities that highlight the ingenuity of people before fancy things like CAD and even calculators...

The underground cable entry/exit viewing area is really neat too, gives you a peek into the underground portion of the cable car system that is normally invisible to normal persons...

Of course there is the gift shop, that sells retired street signs, and pieces of retired cables which is pretty neat...

You probably won't spend all day here (heck you could probably see everything in detail in an hour or two) but its definately worth checking out to appeciate the wondefully obsolete yet still in service cable car system...
author: Frank E.

description:
Get your geek on!  This place rocks!  While you see just about everything the first time you go, whenever I take out of town guests here, I leave them upstairs to imprint a penny with a "San Francisco Cable Car Museum" logo, and I sneak downstairs and just watch the cables whip around the huge flywheels.  Yeah, baby, an actual WORKING museum!  It's still hard to believe the powers that be were going to get rid of the cable cars - the only transportation system listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

AS AN ASIDE: Whatever you do, though, don't live or stay near this place (I lived on Clay Street overlooking the museum for about 6 months.)  This is where they house the cars overnight.  EVERY MORNING at 5 :00 am, the cream of the Muni worker crop (there's an oxymoron for you), obviously jacked up on caffeine (or some other stimulant) sing, yell and otherwise create a ruckus while they take the cars out.  "Watch my foot!" is one thing, but karaoke Anita Baker is quite another.
author: Ms. C.

description: It's free.  Hence the 5 stars. But remember this is one of those places that you stop by at to take a look around while you figure out where the hell you want to go next.  Plus, like I said before, it's free.  It is cool to see an old school rail car and to educate yourself on how cable cars work.  Actually, it's really really cool and really REALLY interesting.  Not only that, you can see the cable system at work.  Think.. it's that ACTUAL cable that moves ALL cable cars on that line.  Plus they have bathrooms.  It's a good stop to come when you're stuck playing "tour guide" for people and you REALLY don't want to go to the Academy of Science for the 60 billionth time.  Or when you're strapped for cash. Or you're running of ideas of where to go and you need a moment to just sit, rest your feet and think about what the hell to do next.
author: Meena N.

description: If you are in SF, you have to stop at this museum.   Allow 30 minutes to see the machinery and read the story behind this (the only) cable car system still in operation.
author: Anne H.

description: One of the greatest places I visited in The City.  It was amazing to see the history and how the history literally lives on daily.  Remarkable engineering and a great open display for all to enjoy.  Its free!
author: Dean P.

description: Love this place. Go see the engines pulling the cables which flow throughout the city and the history of these amazing historic cars. This is a must see.
author: James S.

description:
Although this is high on the list of tourist stops, it is still a must-see part of San Francisco's history.  You can see the actual machinery running the cable cars and learn how all those wheels and cables operate.  It's really fascinating, even to someone like me who isn't particularly mechanically inclined.

Big wheels keep on turning..... etc.
author: H.A. ..

description: This is really the main garage and maintenance facility for SF's cable car fleet.  In addition, this is the hub for the actual cables that run in the streets of San Francisco.  It was very informative and interesting.  This museum provided great insight to the workings of the iconic cable cars that you see in San Francisco.  Very pleasantly surprised but I would not really call it a museum. It's more than that.
author: Al E.

description: Educational for children, the Best part ~~~~ wait for it~~~~  its FREE.
author: Nicole L.

description:
A small but excellent little museum that is free!

If you love the cable cars, then this place is a must.  It has a fantastic history of the cable car, with many old pieces on display including whole original cars.  Parts and pieces are all explained and shown to you so you can understand how the entire cable care system works.  They also show you how the cable car system was almost lost, saved by the public, and then retrofitted to preserve these great forms of transportation.  I know a lot about the great earthquake and fire, but seeing how it practically destroyed the cable car system back in the day was quite interesting.  Seeing pictures of the retrofitting in the 80s is great as you can see what's under the street and how they improved the entire system for the coming years.

Below the museum is the actual area where the cables come through and get returned into the system.  This historic building is not just a museum, it's a functional cable system house!

Keep in mind that if you get off and then on again, you need separate tickets.  But if you have a single or 3 day pass, then be sure to stop by this place and check it out!
author: Shawn M.

description: I love to come here to see how the cable cars work. The display boards give a great explanation. Great for first time riders on the cable car. And the best is its FREE!!
author: Melissa B.

description: Free museums rock, especially when they show off public transport. Cool to just see how th Cable cars work even if you don't really want to understand the mechanics behind em.
author: Matthew M.

description: This was a very interesting museum. After riding onb the cable cars, we were wondering how they work. Someone on the street suggested going to the museum, which is no only on one of the cable car lines but also one percent free. This is a must see thing in San Francisco. Don't forget to go downstairs and see the view underground as well. After visiting the Cable Car Museum, go on the cable car and watch how it all works.
author: Christian H.

description: Great museum!  Pretty small but a good learning experience.  Would have been cool to pull the cable car levers, however ringing the bell was fun enough!  It's one of San Francisco's hidden gems.  Everybody says you need to ride the cable cars in SF, more important is knowing how they work!
author: Nick O.

description:
I always try to take my out-of-town friends here-
It really bugs me how everyone talks about the "trolleys" around SF, so I correct them - "Cable Cars!" and tell them, "Educate yourself!"

So I bring them here - it's FREE and close to dim sum in Chinatown!

Definitely check out the downstairs part - it's small, but really awesome!
author: Chris Y.

description: It was very cool to see how the famous Cable Car's of San Francisco work. The museum is user friendly and good for the whole family. We spent about 40 minutes inside the museum and everyone enjoyed the show. So, Yay! I'm a fan.
author: David R.

description:
I'm a curious guy and when I moved here and lived on Powell St and saw the cable cars every day, I was very curious how they worked and their story. Came here and it all was answered. So cool to see how it all works and it's crazy how all those cables all over the city are controlled in this one spot. 

Also, it's free! What could you ever complain about.
author: Wes K.

description:
Very interesting museum & you can watch the operations of the cable cars in action.  

Allow 30 minutes or so to read all of the displays & watch the show on the 1906 fire.   If there are engineers or DIY engine geeks, you might need more time.

A definite free stop on the Cable Car route & your cable car brakeman will smile when you tell him you're going to the museum.
author: Star M.

description:
Wonderful working museum.  Won't take you that long to see the engines pulling the cables that pull the cable cars.  Several good photo spots and lots of reading for the more interested members of your group.  Walk downstairs for the few minutes it takes to see the pulleys directing the cables and reading the info there.
The gift shop was also better than most and sells pieces of used cable.
And as many reviewers mentioned it is FREE.
author: Bo D.

description: I'm actually quite surprised by how much fun I had here. And I don't consider myself a tourist of SF. Maybe it was the presentation, but still photos and really old tools never looked so interesting. The fact that this is still an actual functioning cable car station with GIANT cogs still pulling the cars made this almost surreal. A definite stop if you're a tourist and even if you're a local you owe it to yourself to visit, no matter what your age.
author: John N.

description: This is a very informative museum dedicated to the history of the San Francisco cable car.  It is still a working repair shop.  There are many pictures from over the years as well as the cables used today to run the cars.  Gives one a real appreciation of the complexity of the ever popular SF cable car system
author: MC B.

description: I stumbled upon this museum while exploring SF and I was pleasantly surprised it was free. Although, I wouldn't pay to visit this place because there isn't much to see. However, it was free and it was interesting to stop by to check out the history of SF's famous cable cars. You can see how they still function today. Pretty neat! Check it out if you have some time to waste and you're in the area.
author: Ron B.

description:
The Cable Car Museum was not so great because of the many artifacts and historical pieces they had, but rather because it's the actual hub of the entire cable car system. They had the requisite old timey cable car coins and tickets, plus photos from the original cable car system to up when the redid it in the early '80s.

But what was really cool, was the 12 huge sheaves that turn the cables that run the cars. The museum part is upstairs so you can overlook the balcony down into the inner workings of the system. You can also go downstairs and see the sheaves that are below ground. I had no idea how the cable cars actually ran until I went here. And it's free!
author: Marjie T.

description:
Not just a museum, but also a fully functioning part of the cable car system. Try to take your eyes off the massive sheaves as they pull the cables that make the different lines in the city run. Take in the history of this quintessential part of the city while thinking to yourself how lucky we are that those misguided folks decades ago didn't get there way and close down the system. Leave with a new appreciation for the romantic and charming vehicles that climb our beautiful streets.

I love this city.
author: Jason B.

description: This was really fun! It's free, informative, and you get to see the actual cables in motion! We didn't end up riding a cable car during our visit, so this was the next best thing. My husband loves reading about history, so this was perfect for him. Lots of stories about the start of the cars, as well as what almost stopped them. I learned a lot, and it was a nice place to check out for an hour.
author: Aly M.

description:
The museum is amazing. I learned so much about the history of cable cars and how they work. It's FREE and INTERESTING! I can't believe cables are still pulling around the cars and that parts of the track it takes about the same amount of time to get through the city as if in a car! Fascinating and fun.  

The cable car history movie explained everything well, the working cables were a marvel to see and the old cable cars housed in the museum were beautiful. Definitely would go back!
author: Kristina V.

description: The San Francisco Cable Car Museum gives a unique insight into the history of a great city. Also it is the actual spot where the cars and other equipment are repaired and the lines themselves are operated. Just about everywhere you look there's something interesting and informative to see.
author: Bruce T.

description: I find it really hard to give this place anything less than 5 stars, considering the cost of admission: FREE! This is a great little museum, is within walking distance from the California Cable Car line, and is a stop on the Powell-Mason and Powell-Hyde routes. Very interesting part of San Francisco history. Also, do pay the 25 cents to look into the picture viewers of the 1906 San Francisco earthquake.
author: Rachael C.

description: You've got to stop by once, if only to see the GE-sponsored film with the singing hobo beard guy music. Seeing the machinery running is magical.
author: Klevin D.

description:
Great for a free museum.

I got to discover the working mechanisms of a cable car which was very fascinating.

Small, takes about 1 hr to 2 hrs to see everything but great way to learn about cable cars and pass time w/o spending $.

Wouldn't come back twice though, since I saw everything thoroughly the first time around.

Convenient location accessible by bus.
author: Cadence C.

description: I had to go here for a homework assignment.  This place is amazing!  Cool exhibits and interesting to watch the cables in motion.  A great place to take tourists and kids.  It does get a little warm in this building, so dress in layers.
author: Trish S.

description:
A little over a year ago, I moved into a shitty lower Nob Hill apartment that I thought was glorious. I shamelessly abused Taylor street in my weekly frolics all the way to the water. And on one of my first frolics, I found the Cable Car Museum.

I was intrigued, informed, and enthralled the way a 5-year old might be by ropes and wheels, despite the fact that I had yet to ride a cable car. I watched those majestic wheels for perhaps an hour. Those powerful pylons, that glorious history, that citywide camaraderie to save what had become part of SF's heart and soul! And free of charge! Yes, sir. This was why I moved to San Francisco. "You have arrived," the Cable Car Museum told me. And I believed it.

A year later and I pass the site of my first epiphany considerably less often, mostly in the company of first-timers. This place holds a fondness in my heart, unrivaled by the budgets and notoriety of the De Young, SF MOMA, Academy of Sciences (though those are all well and good). But I feel a certain comfort in just knowing that it exists; that it remains so that people like me, living in shitty apartments and frolicking through all of the City's least interesting neighborhoods, realize that they have arrived.
author: Amanda F.

description:
After I brought my father here, I couldn't tell him crazy stories about the cable car anymore - dammit!  And before you go thinking I'm mean or something for telling my father wild tales of the cable car being pulled by draft horses in underground caverns so they wouldn't leave too much poop on the streets, you have to understand my childhood.

I can't put my finger on a specific story right now but just to give you an idea - do you remember Calvin & Hobbes?  Remember how Calvin's dad would always tell him some nonsensical answer to one his questions and Calvin would believe it until he got to school and all the kids laughed at him?  My dad was the inspiration for that, I would swear to it.  If I had a question- he had an answer...it just wasn't necessarily a *true* answer. 

So I come by it naturally.  

However, the Cable Car Museum blew all that out of the water.  Not only does it have all kinds of fascinating memorabilia and plaques to read and history to see, it has this fascinating room where you can watch all the cables coming in and out of the powerhouse.

Not a horse in sight.

The Museum is not just for fink fathers though - it's a free all-ages place to take anyone who's ever been intrigued by those mobile little pieces of history.  If you have not been - go.  Go now.
author: Suzanne B.

description:
The cable car museum is a little out of the way but well worth a visit. You can get to it on the cable cars or some turs stop here.

There is a lot of history with San Francisco's cable cars, which is fascinating to read about. You can also see the mechanism which drives the cables under the streets, which the cars latch onto. There's also a great gift shop.

I think San Fran equals cable cars and this adds to the experience.
author: Yee Gan O.

description: This is the best museum in San Francisco...and it's free!  I didn't even know this museum existed until the Brakeman on the Powell-Hyde line announced it at the nearby stop.  My traveling buddy and I took one look at each other and jumped off.  It was so worth it!  We learned a lot about the history of cable cars and how at one point they were almost put out of service.  Not only is this a museum, but it is also the barn where cable cars are parked and repaired.  Furthermore, all of the cables are routed through this facility so you can see what the cables look like underground.  You can also see MUNI employees servicing cables and cable cars.  If you didn't appreciate this 125+ year old transportation system before, you will after a trip here.  You can also learn a little about the history of San Francisco and understand the different between street cars versus cable cars.  There is also a gift shop here for all of your cable car related souvenirs.
author: Courtney K.

description:
This is not just a museum, this is also the Hub Station for the Cable Cars.  I wanted to write a little blurb about these little nifty cars, but didn't really find the right place to post my little blurb.  (Checked Muni, couldn't find info, and checked SFTA, only found pricing info).  So it was logical to me, anyway, to use the CCM as a point of reference.

My Blurb.  

I always thought of the Cable Cars as being more nostalgic than useful.  I would watch the cars pass me by full of folks whom I always assumed to be tourist; and I never ever considered taking a Cable Car to get to points of destination.  

Well, my opinion has changed 180.  I've moved jobs and find myself spending more time downtown...  In the past, I have been forced to take the California 1.  This planned route I believe was created by the evil empire so as to punish those who dwell in areas considered more desirable parts of SF.  In a nutshell, the California 1 is horrible for those who live past Polk St.  The busses are usually full of people packed in like canned sardines.  Most often these busses will pass up those who are waiting at the bus stops.  When I get to the corner of my block and see a cluster of folks, I always no it's a bad day for Muni transit and it's better to walk over to California Street and catch a Cable car.

Okay, off my point here.  

Now that I'm downtown I find I have more transit options, however the one I find most pleasant is the Cable Car line.  I find the passengers to be 50/50 (50% local & 50% tourist), and in all, people are courteous, there's usually a seat available, and unlike the Muni California 1 busses, they do not pack people in like a can of sardines.  Another thing that makes the Cable Car enjoyable is the tourist, dare I say it.  Everyone riding these cars is in a good mood and very excited to ride the world-famous cars, and their mood usually transcends on to the others of the 50 percentile.  Its interesting to hear the conversations between the conductors and the travelers.  I also notice locals are usually generous in giving suggestions or helping with directions to these excited travelers.  

Over all, it's a great experience and one that I now realize I have been missing out.  It has also reminded me that SF is not just a place I call home, but a  beautiful metropolitan city of world travel destination.  I take the cable car as often as possible now.  ;^)
author: Cris B.

description: As for small museums I would give this place four stars.  Not very big and could be more comprehensive.  Sweet to see the machinery in operation and a bonus star for being free to the public.
author: Neil A.

description: As they only city in the United States to still have a functioning cable car system, this museum is a great place to know how they work. If you are wondering why there's always clicking sounds emitting from the ground, they are going to explain all that in the museum. This is a must see when you are in San Francisco.
author: Kwoky L.

description: How many New Yorkers have never been to the Statue of Liberty? Probably as many as the number of San Franciscans who have never visited this small but very educational museum. It's one of the places I always take company from out-of-town, and often one of the places they enjoy the most. A fun learning experience and never crowded, even though it's free. They need a good PR firm to increase the hype, because too many people don't even know it's here.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
As resident of an apartment right the Hyde line and a block away from the California line, San Francisco's famous cable car resonances are ingrained in my daily sonic eco-system. So much so, that when the cable car lines stop momentarily, it usually takes me a second to realize, what is "off" or "wrong". Finally a couple of weekends ago, I was able to stop by and check out the museum.

I love everything here, from the smell (yeah, I'm multisensory like that) to the various informative exhibits to the helpful "talking" displays to the HUGEARSE gears with oldskool signage, lettering dating back to Philly 1892!!

Check it out: 2006 - 1892 = 114 years.  Do you think the Muni bus you rode today is going to be around in 2120 for touristas from Germany, Korea or Argentina to check out ? Funny right? Whadabout that ipod or even the casa in which you live ??

I think that as the aesthetices of industrial design lean increasingly towards "Planned Obsolescence", it is majorly groovy and comforting to see and appreciate the design & engineering from a bygone era and understand the inner workings of the only functional cable-car system in the world!  And it is FREE!!! 5 Stars!! Fast!
author: I. O.

description:
Who knew? That cable cars were interesting and that this little gem of a museum even existed. It's not going to blow your mind, but seeing how the cars originated, what San Francisco looked like back then and after the fire, the size of the cables and how they wear down through use, it was all very interesting and very worth my time. What surprised me most about it was that rather than just serve as a rinky-dink ode to the past and a nostalgic transportation system, it was educational about the city.

It was a relaxing way to start a day of sightseeing and the fact that it was totally central in the city means more people can take advantage of the free resource. It was also interesting to see how small a space is used to run the few remaining cars and how the whole system works, even for someone who's never ridden one (I know, how could I not get the cheesy photo op in, right?).
author: Ayelet I.

description:
There is no better place than this to get a real feeling for what holds this city together. I've lived here all my life and I have to say, the Cable Car Museum is dazzling and stunning! Don't let the fact that it's a 'museum' scare you. You need to go there.

The price is unbelievable because it's free! Can't believe it but it's true! You get to read and learn about the history of the cable cars and see, feel and touch important historical artifacts and really get a true sense of the mechanics of what is  a working historical landmark. The giant pulleys hauling the miles and miles of cable which runs under our city streets are truly magnificent and mesmerizing. 

Oh yes, almost forgot. There is a particular hot metal, burnt wood smell which permeates the area and once you smell it (It won't give you asthma or make you faint, just buck up, will you?) - you'll recognize that smell on the city streets when a cable car is nearby and the wind is just right. It's the cable car's brake smell, caused by moving cable caught between two blocks of wood. To know that smell is to be a true San Franciscan.

Can't say a bad thing about this place. Oh wait, I CAN - parking. The street parking sucks but then what ELSE is new? I can't blame them for sucky parking. Be patient, and maybe the parking gods will shower you with good karma, like they did for me, and grant you a space a stone's throw from the entrance. Good luck. (The thing to learn here is to leave early and allow time for parking or take public transportation.)

Just go there and see for yourself. The gift shop has affordable items (don't worry, the expensive items are there too) and the staff was extremely helpful during my visit! Great!
author: Van D.

description:
It is pretty noisy in the Cable Car Museum, but the experience is worth the noise. Not only is it free, but you can learn about how the cable cars work and the history where the cable cars used to travel in the city. It is a great place to kind of put together not only the fact that we use cable cars to travel, but that they take a lot of maintenance and care.

In order to fully appreciate the experience of riding a cable car, you need to go here to see the cables and wheels turning.
author: Glaciala A.

description:
It's small as all hell, so thank god it's free.

My trip here was interesting in spite of how brief it was. The cable car replica in the back makes for a great photo opportunity. 

There is a touchscreen display of the various models MUNI currently uses for the F-Line. It's so cool how each of them are vintage streetcars from not only San Francisco but all over the world as well (they have streetcars that were used in Australia, England and Italy). Just touch the picture of each streetcar model on the screen if you want to know more about it. 

Outside of that, it's basically a large gift store. It's a much more interesting than usual gift store with books about public transit history as well as SF knick knacks which are beyond your standard keychain and postcard fare. 

Not gonna lie, I was expecting more, but it's ~*FREE*~ so I can't really complain.
author: Philippe C.

description:
This is a must see for those that are into mechanics (like myself).  As people have mentioned, it's free.  Really cool information and displays on how the cable car system works.  Sit down and watch the video.  Even though it's a little dated it was extremely informative and interesting.  Ever wonder how the cable is routed through the city?  Corners?  Hills and dips?  Here are all the answers.

I even found myself just sitting and watching the motors spin the giant pulley's that power the different lines.  Impressive.
I ended up buying a section of cable as a memento (my girlfriend just rolled her eyes).  You can buy one at the little gift store.  Metal, machines, motors, wood,... I love this stuff.  Highly recommend for anyones tourist destination list.
author: Anthony L.

description: We dropped in here (since it's FREE!) and spent 15-20 minutes looking around.  We probably could have spent longer, but we enjoyed just seeing how the cable cars work.  It might not be the most exciting thing we did in SF, but it was great for a place to just step in and look around.
author: Meg B.

description:
FREE MUSEUM to the public. The pulleys and trolley system is explained at this museum.  

If you happen to be on the cable car line, stop in here.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
I found this FREE museum welcome entertainment as I thought I knew how the system worked.  It was fun to get this confirmed by seeing it in action.

Lots of historical information available on how the cable cars started.  Lots of information on how the system continues to work.  Pretty neat to see as an engineer and I think its neat to see if you aren't too.

Besides its free and you can see it all in like 20 minutes.
author: Brian M.

description: No touristy trip to SF would be complete without this museum. Granted I'm not the type of person who's super interested in stuff like public transportation and how it works but I have a friend who is so we decided to come here and check it out. No regrets at all. Love that it's free. Plus now I understand how cable cars work and I must admit they're pretty hardcore!
author: Constance C.

description:
A fun way to spend 20 minutes if you are visiting the city. The huge cables are loud and smell funky, but its all part of the charm. 

You can take a look back at San Francisco in the books they have at the gift shop. I also picked up a great SF ornament at Christmas time. The whole shop is not large, but the prices are not too expensive and the atmosphere is interesting.
author: Natalie N.

description: Get serious and visit the Cable Car Museum. Breathtaking view, not like on the roofs of Paris but of engines and the operation of cable cars. The museum features three former trams dating from 1870, many photographs chronicling the history of cable cars but also tools such as the clutch wedge clamp system.
author: Jen C.

description:
So fun to learn about the history of San Francisco and how the cable cars work.

Best to match with a day in Chinatown & end with and evening in North Beach.
author: Valerie F.

description: Pretty neat museum. You get to see the central operation of where all the cable cars are powered. You can see old cars, learn how everything works and learn the history of the system. If you look at and read everything in the place it will probably take 45 minutes to get through. So it is a pretty quick stop but really fun and informative to learn about a really unique public transport system in SF. Also, I learned there that you can get an unlimited ride pass on the cable cars for $14, I wish I would have known that when I first got to SF.
author: Patrick G.

description: If you've ever ridden a cable car in Frisco, this place is worthy visiting.  Lots of history to go around. Amazing
author: val a.

description:
I'm a huge dork when it comes to cable cars. How they work completely fascinates me and the museum is the place to bring your family and friends so they can geek out too. They're such an important part of San Francisco's history...not to mention they get me home after I've been schlepping around Union Square. Sure, the tourists act a little goofy once in a while but it sure is a nice way to get around. 

Where else could you spend $45/month on transportation and have access to moving landmarks like these?? 

I told you I was a dork.
author: lindsay w.

description:
This museum isn't just for show, they are there to educate and restore old trolly cars from all over (not just original models from San Francisco).  Once these trains are functional, they give them to the MUNI system and become the cars we ride today on the F-Line. 

The shop has some great educational material.  Or you can cheat (like I do) and talk to the staff.  They are full of information and very passionate about the efforts.
author: Christopher P.

description: It's free, it has cool photos of old San Francisco, and it's something that you can only find in the city.
author: Laralynne B.

description: So cool and FREE! How could you not love it? This is not just a museum, but the actual cable garage where the cables run 24/7! If you're visiting, def. stop by... it's right off of the Hyde-Mason line and the conductor will tell you when you're there.
author: Robynne W.

description:
This museum is really cool and I would give it 5 stars except for the fact that it is really hard to breath inside.  It smells like grease and dust.  Once you get over that fact, you will appreciate the interesting information, pictures and artifacts.  The fact that you can see the huge motors and cables moving really makes the museum come alive.  It is great for all ages.

For more information about FREE museums in the Bay Area check out this link:
http://www.examiner.com/x-20478-Oakland-Museum-Examiner~y2009m8d20-Top-5-Bay-Area-museums-with-free-days?#comments
author: Tim D.

description:
One of the more unique and least-visited parts of San Francisco.  This "museum" is the actual powerhouse for the Cable Cars that traverse our fair city.  One can learn about the complex artisanship of cable splicing, watch the sheaves under the street relaying the cable for the lines, and of course observe the giant electric engines themselves powering the California, Hyde, Powell and Mason Street cable loops.

Oh, and did I mention is free?
author: Jim W.

description:
A hidden treasure in the city. Cool for kids, and adults too.
Hard to believe it is free ... although if you hop off the cable car and pay to get on again, it is an extra $5.
author: Meredith G.

description:
The San Francisco Cable Car Museum is a free museum detailing cable car history along with current operations and maintenance. This museum is right off the Hyde and Mason cable car lines in Nob Hill. The building and display area are relatively small but full of interesting pictures and history. For the mechanically inclined, you can see how the cable cars are operated. Once you find out maybe you wouldn't get back on one. (check out the braking system- do you smell something burning). 

Anyway you can finish this point of interest in an hour or so. It is a nice quick stop on your way or before braving the circus that is union square and Fisherman's wharf.
author: Lance H.

description:
I still remember vividly when I came here as a child. When I first came to the SF Cable Car museum on a school tour, I started getting fascinated with old machinery and how large and bulky they were. Cable Cars, being one of the "natural" symbols of San Francisco, had a history I never knew.

I returned a few months ago while I was in Chinatown for a few hours, and decided to walk around. And I still had that wide-eyed child's feeling as I paced around this fascinating exhibit that is part of San Francisco History.
author: Michael C.

description: This is a super cool museum. Loud. Bring earplugs. Be willing to put some effort into walking/parking/getting there. FUN! TRULY FUN! Best thing ever for guests/visitors if you can figure out a convenient way to schlep over there.
author: p v.

description:
This is pretty cool, and educational.  I definite must stop for the out of towners.  It is pretty to the point, no frills.   The best part is the downstairs view of the cables. . . I wish it had more light.

I agree with Gourmet G, a good PR firm, and possibly even a benefit event to raise some cash, and these guys could put the finishing touches on what is already a great place.
author: C M.

description:
A must for a visitor and local alike. Here one can learn about the early days of San Francisco, the distruction on the 1906 earthquake, and start to really appreciate the cable cars and yearn for the old days when there were 20 lines instead of 4.

The museum is free.
author: Anya B.

description:
I had a great time here. I liked that is was free! I also like that there were plenty of things to read.

I suppose it would have gotten five stars if there was an option for a tour with hardhats and all through the area where people are actually working.
author: Stu M.

description: The Cable Car Museum is a "must-see" for any passenger of San Francisco's famous cable cars. How else are you going to know how the cable cars negotiate those crazy San Francisco hills?! And since the two most popular cable car lines (Powell-Hyde and Powell-Mason) pass right by the front door, there's no excuse not to hop off for a quite visit. The museum (actually a working museum, since most of the building is taken up by the motors and the working parts of the cable car system) is small enough that it doesn't take much time to see everything. Although, train geeks could easily spend the better part of a day there watching the pulleys and cables go round and round!!
author: John F.

description:
Things don't get much cooler than this.  Seriously Old School.  We are talking 1800s technology displayed where oddly they sell retired 1940s to 1960s era San Francisco street signs as well. 

Your tax dollars are at work here in the best way.  The CC Barn and Museum does not make a profit, yet this is where anyone coming to town learns how this unique attraction actually functions.

Short on time?  No problem, you can be in and out in 20 minutes, but do not forget to go downstairs to see how things work beneath the streets.  Better yet, when done, grab a coffee across the street at the Gallery Cafe!
author: Alex H.

description:
Top marks to the Cable Car Barn and Museum.


 It's a little hard to explain, but you do actually get to see the actual working winding gear that is powering the cable cars that are running past you outside in the street. Fascinating, for those with a tendency towards anorak interests.


 Theres also some old cable cars and artifacts to look at.


 Being on the actual cable car route this is an easy attraction to add to your itinerary if you are riding the cable car to/from Fishermans Wharf.


 Allow half an hour, or half a day for real anoraks.
author: macallister

description: We came across this place while walking up to Grace Cathedral on a sunny afternoon. What was amazing was the functioning cable car system. A lot of things to see and read. Best of all, it was free :)
author: Ashley B.

description: This museum is free, amazing, and interesting. One of the best things I've ever done in SF. Make sure you walk down stairs when you walk through the door. You will see working massive wheels under the intersection. Great for anyone young or old. Very interesting and worthwhile.
author: Adam B.

description: Do go here if you like cable cars, have children, or are interested in public transportation. Don't go here if you are prone to migraines, hate the smell of autoshops, or have a short attention span. I'm sorry i'm not as sentimental as the other reviewers but big wheels never did it for me.  Granted, it was very cool for the 7 minutes pre-migraine.
author: Jane K.

description: Awesome place. Under ground view of cable system is amazing once you realize how long ago it was built and just how far it travels. 9 y.o. Boy and cable cars great combo! We had a blast
author: J D.

description: I happened upon this small museum by chance when I first moved here... The huge wheels that turn the cables that move the cars were really cool and its neat to see the mechanical side of something that most probably take for granted.
author: Kyla B.

description:
hey, it's free...it's a little noisy and smells of machine oil.

feel how heavy a piece of the cable is on the counter of the gift shop and check out the old street signs for sale....great ol'skool pictures too!
author: Adam P.

description: This place is super.  If you have friends from out of town who happen to be engineers (you poor son of a #*$%!), then take them to this place and they will be amused for quite some time.  Neat little museum.
author: Renate V.

description: I wish I had known of this quirky and informative museum when my curious, mechanically minded son was young.  The inner workings of the entire cable car system are laid wonderfully bare.  Lots to see and plenty of clear explanations to read.  A great selection of photographs from the aftermath of the great quake and fire.  A serious uphill walk from Union Square but it leaves you ready for the next great SF meal.
author: Ash A.

description:
Update, I went by the museum after I left Gallery Cafe and it's absolutely amazing in there.  You can see how the Cable car works and it tells you the history of it all.  I get a high just from watchig the hug wheel turn, working the cables.  Don't forget to go downstair where all the action is.  It's deffinitely a landmark of SF.  A must check out if you have a little extra time.

To tell the truth, I've never even been in there yet and I'm right across the street from it at the Gallery Cafe.  Anyway, just from meeting the guy that works in there two days ago when I was walking by it with my sister in law and niece.  I have to say he's one of the nices guy I've met and from what my sister in law told me, he's super nice to the kids around here.  He even gave my sister in law's sister some gift and money to spend when they were younger (they live right at this block).  How sweet is that?  If such a great guy works there, how bad could the place be.  I heard that he been working there for many many years.  He was about to give a gift to my new niece when we were walking by.   How sweet is that.  He's like a friend to all the kid that's hang around there.  There's this recreation center right at the other corner.  You can play pingpong in there, but it's mostly asian kids in there.
author: Xiu L.

description: The cable car museum is a great part of California history and San Francisco history. Cable cars are great to ride in and are great to see many areas of San Francisco. You also get to learn about the mechanics of cable cars. For those that know a lot about cable cars, you might learn something new here as well.
author: DJ Guan Yu M.

description: I agree wholeheartedly with Jonathan.  This building epitomizes our City's illustrious mass transit evolutionary history.  Not only is this a museum, but its also the central cable works from which the entire system is run; the "guts", if you will.   There is something totally compelling about the powerful wheels - ancient yet formidable - and driving cable lines that make an urban geography dork like me gaze at length.
author: Rick H.

description: This is not your typical museum.  Sure they've got old photographs, artifacts, and fully-restored cable cars on display, as well as a nice souvenir shop, but it's so much more than that.  You're taken into the heart of the beast:  the smell of motor oil in the air, the roar of generators and turning gears, and the actual cables spinning directly in front of your face.  Lots to discover about the inner-workings of the cable-car system and how it played a role in SF history.  So much (FREE) fun and a perfect place for those Mr. and Ms. Fix-It types who go ga-ga over how things work.  I highly recommend this museum to everyone, locals and tourists alike--it'll leave you with an even deeper appreciation for this fair city!
author: Andrea U.

description: Fun and free -- you can't beat it! Simply calling this a museum doesn't do it justice, because it's more than that. This is the fully functional central powerhouse of the entire San Francisco cable car system. Every cable car in the city is powered from here, and you can get up close and personal to see how it all works. The place is filled with historical pictures and interesting facts -- who knew some cable cars survived the 1906 earthquake and are still in use today? I didn't. This is a vital part of San Francisco history, and this museum is a great way to appreciate it.
author: Jason B.

description: Cable cars are part of what made Victorian San Francisco so special. So pay some homage to the historic system and visit the Cable Car Museum. The museum, (free!) will remind you why you love it here. The actual cables that run all 10.5 miles of cable car track go through this facility, and they're featured prominently from a vantage point above the machinery. Old cable car stuff and 1906 earthquake photos abound, and, for penny collectors out there, there is a flattened penny machine right in the front door. Tough area for parking and the people running it were fairly grumpy the day I was there (i.e. locking the front door at closing time without telling the many people still inside how to get out), but I highly recommend this place for locals and/or their out-of-towners.
author: Tara R.

description:
In a massively expensive city, this small museum in one of China Town's nicest streets, is a really fun and educational place to visit.  Free and educational.....love it.

Add to that, the same facility serves as the functioning center of cable cars...wow, really cool!
author: The P.

description: I love museums. I really like places that reveal complex systems, like when a hole opens up in the ground and you see tons of cables. This is a combination- the interpretations are long paragraphs that I haven't even read through yet, but I like just watching the cables run along the sheaves. Neat-o. Small, quick, interesting, and it really explained cable cars better than any verbal explanations I've ever receivd. FREE.
author: Anna B.
