description: Came here many times as a kid . Basically , what you will learn in this museum is how the cable car works and the history behind the cable car . You will also get to see how the cable car works . I think the museum is just to make tourists want to take the cable car . Personally , I think this museum is kinda boring . But hey , it's free .. doesn't hurt to check it out if you have some free time on your hands and haven't checked it out yet . Just note that it's really hard to breathe inside the museum ..
author: Eileen L.

description: I expected to go in to the Cable Car Museum and read a bunch of signs and see a bunch of pictures about the history of the cable cars. I would have liked that just fine - I'm a history museum fan. (Especially when they're free.) I had no idea that I'd walk in and see the actual cables and mechanisms that make them work!! This was very, very cool... I like to know how things work and this is an impressive system. Each cable car ride I take makes living in this city a little bit better. Thank god they accept FastPasses...
author: Carmen B.

description: It's free, which is why this gets a lot of stars already. Nothing much else spectacular about this place beyond that. It's interesting if you want to know how the cable cars are run, but it doesnt really do anything for other than that. The location is sort of random and inconvenient by car. If you take some people from out of town, this would probably work better, but yeah...nothing too special for the locals
author: Dustin H.

description: All the cables that run the cable cars, are run by the drives here in the museum. Feel the pride when you read about how the trams were saved from being scrapped, and fully refurbished in the 80's.
author: Ed R.

description: What a neat little museum and free admission too. I've lived in SF for a little over a year and have never taken a cable car ride, mostly because it seems like a touristy thing to do. Well, I changed my mind after going to this museum. You will leave with a new appreciation for these cable cars, I guarantee it. We all jumped on one after leaving and ended up chatting with the operator. Turns out that only 4 out of 200 people passed the grueling "cable car operator" test which only occurs every 2 years. Anyway, check it out, even if for only for 15 minutes. I would have given 5 stars, but the guy working the gift shop was a REAL dud when we asked some very simple questions regarding the Hyde cable car route.
author: S A R A H.

description: I like this - very cool breakdown of the technology and history of cable cars.  Worth a trip.
author: Matthew C.

description: I used to live across the street from this museum, even before it turned into a museum.  I like coming here to see old pictures of San Francisco, it always amazes me how much the city has changed.
author: Kit E.

description: Fascinating engineering idea  for something implemented  and created about 110 years ago and Mr. Hallidae's great grandaughter's first name is Hallidae...she's a pretty smart finance person and did a mean lindy dance at a Christmas party!! Take or recommend out of towners visit this museum because the cable cars were one of the most effective ways of going up the California street hill between Grant and Powell. Then try walking that hill in 5 minutes and you cut back on about 50 steps on the stairmaster...
author: miriam b.

description: This is a great, simple museum, and I love to take people (especially kids) here  to see how the cable cars work.
author: jen n.

description: Kids love this place. it's great to see the cables running through their wheels, disappearing into the depths of the ground
author: Ben G.

description: It's not fancy, but it's really cool to see & learn how the system works, how they keep it running, how often it gets repaired, etc.  Also, they have some great old 3-d photo machines from the earthquake which are amazing.  And it's FREE!
author: Don H.

description: After sitting in the window of the Gallery Cafe all morning the museum beckoned.  It was free, afterall.  I am generally not very interested in how mechanical objects work.   This place was pretty cool, though, I must admit.  You actually get to see how the cable cars work underground.  And there are lots of neat historical photos of the city.  The posters are unintelligible.  Even with several advanced degrees under my belt, I was not able to decipher them.  I'm going to bring my Dad when he comes to the city for a visit.  Maybe he can explain it to me.
author: sarah k.

description: I'm an engineer, so perhaps this kind of stuff excites me more than others.  With that said, this was a fun way to spend 20 minutes.  The displays are informative and I left with a better appreciation for the cable car conductors and gripsmen that make it all run.
author: Adam W.

description: Like the Conductor said last week when I was riding the Cable Car past the museum, " Next stop, Cable Car Museum.  It's free." It is pretty cool to see the giant cable that pull the cars.
author: Amme P.

description: It's a cool little free museum.  Not sure when, but It's been recently updated so visitors can get up close and personal with some of the original equipment and trolleys. The gift store's very touristy but it was a fun insight into some of SF's great history.  Noisy though-you can see the "cables" that service the City's remaining three lines.
author: Jen L.

description: Gives you a sense of the ridiculous scale employed in maintaining what is now a toy public transit system.  You really haven't seen San Francisco until you've seen these huge GE motors throwing the cable system in all directions, winding them every which way around the huge pulleys.  The museum also carries this latent low-percentage threat of grisly accidental death, which is cool too.
author: Mike O.

description: Although I live in this city ... I have never stopped by the cable car museum before even with the free admission.  I came here a few days ago with my students on a mini field trip, they were ecstatic to see how the cable car works.  You get to see the cable that keep the trolleys running. You can see photos of how the old cable cars looked and a short film/documentary on cable cars.  Be sure to stop at the gift shop for your cable car souvenir.
author: Jen P.

description: I remember going here when I was real little, but the images stay in your head forever.  If you don't quite get how the historic and legendary cable system works, then go here and find out.
author: Jonathan B.

description: If you're making a list of places to go with your out-of-town visitors this should be near the top of the list. A vital piece of San Francisco history and something they'll always remember. The story of public transportation in the Bay Area is not a pretty one,at least not for the past 50 years,so it's nice to recall a time when moving around The City was quick and inexpensive,and fun. The cable car system was an engineering marvel,and this museum is a fitting memorial.
author: Dan Y.

description: Truly one of those San Francisco secrets, the *FREE* Cable Car Museum is a piece of living history.  You get to watch the engines that turn the wheels that pull the cable of every cable car line in the city.  When you stop to consider there were over 20 cable car lines in SF at one point, you'll appreciate what you see here.  This is on the checklist of places to take out-of-towners to once you've exhausted Chinatown and North Beach.  Added bonus: they sell the actual old embossed black and white street signs in the gift shop!
author: Don O.

description: Part historical, part "how it works". It's amazing to see the action that pulls the cable cars up and down the hill of San Francisco!
author: Coco K.

description:
if you loved the cable cars then you will love this. my dad really wanted to go here but i was a little sceptical as i thought it would be boring but i was pleasently suprised. it was very interesting and you got to see exactly how they work and the history of cable cars.
as far as i can remember, the museum is free but there is a place to leave donations which are greatly needed for the running costs.
its a super place to visit if you want to do more than just ride on a cable car!
author: blondi1

description:
A HIDDEN GEM!

We live here and stumbled upon this many times... finally decided to go in. It was super neat to see how the cars work and check out the memorabilia. Definitely worth a stop when you're in the area. Unique, not like just another random museum you could go to in any other big city.
author: suz q.

description: Great place to learn about the history and technology behind cable cars. Plus, you get to see the actual cables pulling all lines in SFO. Free entry!
author: Matthias J.

description:
free.  it should get six stars.

the only thing that sucks here is the parking situation, but if you're patient, you can probably find one that opens up.

less crowds here than the ones that are trying to board the actual cable car.  the musuem offers a ton of educational insights about the history of cable cars and even has an area in the back where you can read about the various disasters that have hit SF (fires, earthquakes, etc.).  complete with videos.  restrooms available and there is a gift shop inside.
author: Bryce K.

description: Why are there no cable cars sitting inside the Cable Car Museum"?  Of course, they are out on the street.  Take a ride on one before or after seeing this "museum".  This place shows you what makes them MOVE! It's really quite an amazing system. And what a delight to offer this for free (well, you do pay for it when you take that cable car ride).
author: Karen-n-Rick C.

description: I can't believe some people here are complaining about parking at a museum dedicated to public transportation.  Come on people, it's right in the heart of the city, right on the cable car lines, and near plenty of bus lines.  Take public transportation!  San Francisco is a CITY...if you want plenty of easy free parking, go to Walnut Creek.
author: Nathan C.

description: it's free. i've came here once with friends. it's a pretty small museum, but full of history about cable cars, pretty nice. i didn't like the smell of this place too much, cus i never liked the smell of the motor? it's also loud inside because of the motors running rapidly.
author: Valerie N.

description: my inner child wanted to go to the exploratorium, but my inner adult did not want to pay the 13 bucks.  so my inner adult took my inner child to the cable car museum.  my inner child then reminded my inner adult that my inner child was, in fact, a girl.  my inner adult said "be quiet, it is free."  my inner child then sulked in the corner.  my inner adult marveled at the cables.  we reconciled over coffee later, which, in retrospect, is not something you should really give children- inner or otherwise.  but the cable car museum is free.  and fun.  but mostly free.
author: Samantha W.

description: It is fascinating to see the often ignored magic behind the whole cable car network.  This building is the Washington/Mason cable car barn and powerhouse which gives you a first hand look how the cables are run and the massive motors that push them through the streets of our city.  The museum carries a thorough history of the cable cars and many exhibits which demonstrate how the mechanics of the whole system works down to the car brakes.  Theres also plenty of information about cable repairs, tools of the trade, and even a display of several historic cable cars.  While I feel there could be a little more information from a locals perspective and the place doesn't take very long to get through, just as the other yelper's stated its free and I've always found it clean.  The whole museum is excellent for the slim budget they must be operating under and I recommend it to everyone who has not been here before.
author: Paige C.

description: My favourite small museum in San Francisco. All my visitors get taken here and without exception they have been fascinated by it. The museum is located in a building that survived the '06 quake and which was the powerhouse for many of the cable car lines. It now serves as the cable car barn for the remaining lines, houses the electric motors that drive the cables, and contains the informative museum. In addition to all the machinery, I was fascinated by all the displays regarding the struggle to save SF's cable cars post-WWII. Oh, and don't forget to go down below street level to see the pulleys and cables as they thread their way under Mason and Washington streets.
author: Colin M.

description: free admission. you can actually see what's under the cable car tracks and i saw those amazing huge wheel used to move the cable cars.
author: Kelly L.
